revision.text:
{{Year box}} [[File:Calcutta Cup 1892.jpg|Right|thumb|350px|[[Rugby football]] – [[England national rugby union team|England]] plays [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] for the [[Calcutta Cup]] in 1892]] '''1892 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Yale Bulldogs football|Yale Bulldogs]]
'''Non-college amateur championships''' * [[Western Pennsylvania Professional Football Circuit|Western Pennsylvania champions]] – [[Allegheny Athletic Association]]
'''Events''' * September 28 – The first [[Night game|night football game]] is attempted between [[1892 Wyoming Seminary vs. Mansfield State Normal football game|Wyoming Seminary and Mansfield State]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/17/AR2006111701688.html|work=[[Washington Post]]|title=Good Night | date=18 November 2006}}</ref> * 12 November – [[William Heffelfinger|William "Pudge" Heffelfinger]] is paid $500 by the [[Allegheny Athletic Association]] to play in a game against the [[Pittsburgh Athletic Club (football)|Pittsburgh Athletic Club]]. He is considered the first professional football player of all time.<ref name="larrynames">{{cite book |last1=Names |first1=Larry D |editor1-first=Greg |editor1-last=Scott |title=The History of the Green Bay Packers: The Lambeau Years |volume=1 |year=1987 |publisher=Angel Press of WI |isbn=0-939995-00-X |pages=24–25 |chapter=The Myth }}</ref>
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 42 points, [[Preston North End]] 37, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 36, [[Aston Villa]] 30, [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] 28, [[Wolverhampton Wanderers|Wolves]] 26 * [[1892 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[West Bromwich Albion]] 3–0 [[Aston Villa]] in the last final to be played at [[The Oval]]. * 13 March — [[Liverpool Football Club]] is founded after [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] is split by a faction fight at board level over the proposed purchase of the freehold at [[Anfield]]. One faction, retaining the club's name and players, quits Anfield and moves across [[Stanley Park, Liverpool|Stanley Park]] to establish a new home at [[Goodison Park]]. The other faction, which owns Anfield, decides to establish a new club there and this is called Liverpool F.C.. The new club joins the Lancashire League prior to the 1892–1893 season. * With the demise of the rival [[Football Alliance]], the Football League is able to expand by inviting former Alliance members to join it. Membership doubles from 14 to 28 clubs with divisions introduced for the first time in the [[1892–93 in English football|1892–93]] season. The original Football League becomes the new [[Football League First Division|First Division]], expanded to 16 teams; and the new [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] is formed with 12 teams, many of them former members of the Alliance. * [[Darwen F.C.|Darwen]] is relegated from the First Division; Newton Heath ([[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]), [[Nottingham Forest]] and [[Sheffield Wednesday]] are elected to the First Division for 1892–93. Members of the new Second Division are Ardwick ([[Manchester City]]), [[Bootle F.C. (1879)|Bootle]] (league members 1892–93), [[Burton United FC|Burton United]] (1892–1907), [[Crewe Alexandra]], [[Darwen F.C.|Darwen]], [[Grimsby Town]], [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]], [[Northwich Victoria]] (1892–94), [[Port Vale F.C.|Burslem Port Vale]] (1892–1907), [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], Small Heath ([[Birmingham City]]) and [[Walsall FC|Walsall]]. '''Germany''' * 25 July — [[Hertha BSC|Hertha Berlin]] founded as one of the oldest clubs in Germany '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Dumbarton F.C.|Dumbarton]] * [[1892 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] 5–1 [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]] at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox Park]] * The SFL is reduced to 10 teams for 1892–93 after [[Cambuslang F.C.|Cambuslang]] and [[Vale of Leven F.C.|Vale of Leven]] are expelled.
==[[Athletics (track and field)]]== '''Events''' * [[C. B. Fry]] equals the world record for the [[long jump]] of 23 ft. 5in – the record stands for 18 months.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * The "National League and American Association" is the sole [[Major League Baseball|major league]] in baseball after incorporating four clubs from the former [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]] into the expanded and restructured [[National League]] and buying out the four others. * The National League plays a split season, [[Boston Beaneaters]] winning the first half, [[Cleveland Spiders]] winning the second. At the end of the season, Boston defeats Cleveland 5–0 in a championship series. The experiment will not be repeated but it will be adapted after two-month interruption of the [[1981 in baseball|1981]] season.
==[[Basketball]]== '''Events''' * January 15 – [[James Naismith]]'s rules for basketball are published for the first time in the [[Springfield, Massachusetts|Springfield]] YMCA International Training School's newspaper, in an article titled "A New Game." They said it was called "Basketball." * March 11 – First basketball game played in public, between students and faculty at the Springfield YMCA.<ref name=Republican>{{cite news | title = Basket Football Game | newspaper = Springfield Republican | location = [[Springfield, Massachusetts]] | date = March 12, 1892 | url = http://www.rarenewspapers.com/view/206238 | accessdate = June 9, 2014}}</ref> The final score was 5–1 in favor of the students, with the only goal for the faculty being scored by [[Amos Alonzo Stagg]].<ref name=Republican/> A crowd of 200 spectators watched the game.<ref name=Republican/>
[[File:James corbett 1890.jpg|Right|thumb|150px|[[James J. Corbett]], known as "Gentleman Jim"]]
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 7 September — [[James J. Corbett]] wins the [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship with a 21st round knockout of [[John L. Sullivan]] at the [[Olympic Club (New Orleans)|Olympic Club]] in New Orleans. Sullivan is gradually worn down by Corbett's combination of elusive footwork and fast jabs. Corbett holds the title until 1897.<ref name="JJC">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/corbett.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – James J Corbett]. Retrieved on 14 November 2009.</ref> '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hg1si20f?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |archivedate=2009-06-20 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-20 |df= }}</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[John L. Sullivan]] → [[James J. Corbett]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Bob Fitzsimmons]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – vacant → [["Mysterious" Billy Smith]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack McAuliffe (boxer)|Jack McAuliffe]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[George Dixon (boxer)|George Dixon]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * The [[English cricket team in Australia in 1891–92]] tours Australia and Ceylon. The team, captained by [[W G Grace]], is organised by [[Lord Sheffield]] who later subscribes his [[Sheffield Shield]] to Australian domestic [[first-class cricket]]. 29 matches are played in total, of which 12 are won, two lost and 15 drawn. Eight of the games are first–class including three [[Test cricket|Tests]] versus [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]]. Australia win the Test series 2–1 to claim [[The Ashes]]. * Beginning of [[first-class cricket]] in India as the annual [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Presidency Matches]] between the [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] and the [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] are recognised as the inaugural first-class fixtures. Soon afterwards, the inaugural first-class tour of India by an overseas team takes place when [[Martin Hawke, 7th Baron Hawke|Lord Hawke]] organises his [[Lord Hawke's XI cricket team in Ceylon and India in 1892–93|1892–93 English touring team]]. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Surrey CCC|Surrey]] * Most runs – [[Herbie Hewett]] 1407 @ 35.17 (HS 201) * Most wickets – [[J. T. Hearne|J T Hearne]] 163 @ 15.39 (BB 9–41) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year|Wisden Five Batsmen of the Year]] – [[Herbie Hewett]], [[Lionel Palairet]], [[Walter Read]], [[Stanley Scott]], [[Andrew Stoddart]] '''Australia''' * Most runs – [[Jack Lyons (cricketer)|Jack Lyons]] 557 @ 55.70 (HS 145) * Most wickets – [[George Giffen]] 50 @ 17.30 (BB 9–96) '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – not contested '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – not contested
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1892 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Harold Hilton]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[John Ball (golfer)|John Ball]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * 11 May — [[African-American]] jockey [[Alonzo Clayton|Alonzo "Lonnie" Clayton]], aged 15, becomes the youngest rider ever to win the [[Kentucky Derby]] '''England''' * [[1892 Grand National|Grand National]] – Father O'Flynn * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[La Fleche (horse)|La Fleche]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Bona Vista]] * [[1892 Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Sir Hugo]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – La Fleche * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – La Fleche '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Glenloth '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – O'Donohue '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Springfield Maid * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Roy Neil '''USA''' * [[1892 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Azra * [[Preakness Stakes]] – ''not run'' * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Patron
==[[Ice hockey]]== * 10 January — [[Ottawa Hockey Club]] defeats the [[Montreal Hockey Club]] 4–3 to become [[Amateur Hockey Association of Canada]] (AHAC) champions * 2 March — Ottawa Hockey Club wins its second consecutive [[Ontario Hockey Association]] (OHA) title, defeating Toronto Osgoode Hall 10–4. * 7 March — Montreal Hockey Club defeats Ottawa 1–0 to regain the AHAC title for the fifth consecutive year. * 18 March — At a [[1891–92 Ottawa Hockey Club season#Celebration dinner|celebration dinner]] to honour the Ottawa Hockey Club, Canadian Governor-General [[Lord Stanley]] announces his new trophy to be awarded to the ice hockey champions of Canada. Originally known as the "Dominion Hockey Challenge Cup", it becomes known as the [[Stanley Cup]], the championship trophy of the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL). * 11 November — The [[Manitoba Hockey Association]] is founded to organize ice hockey play in [[Manitoba]].
==[[Ice skating]]== '''Events''' * The [[International Skating Union]], the world governing body for ice skating, is founded in the Netherlands.
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 9 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 49th [[The Boat Race 1892|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * The [[1892 Home Nations Championship|10th series]] is contested by [[England national rugby union team|England]], [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]], [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] and [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]. England wins all its three games to take the title.
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Wilfred Baddeley]] (GB) defeats [[Joshua Pim]] (Ireland) 4–6 6–3 6–3 6–2 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Lottie Dod]] (GB) defeats [[Blanche Bingley Hillyard]] (GB) 6–1 6–1 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Schopfer]] defeats [[Fassitt]] (GB) 6–2 1–6 6–2 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Oliver Campbell]] defeats [[Fred Hovey]] 7–5 3–6 6–3 7–5 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Mabel Cahill]] (GB) defeats [[Elisabeth Moore]] 5–7 6–3 6–4 4–6 6–2
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}

{{Infobox football tournament season | title = 2006–07 [[Serbian Cup]] | year = | other_title = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | country = {{SRB}} | num_teams = 32 | defending champions = | champions = [[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]] | runner-up = [[FK Vojvodina|Vojvodina]] | matches = 31 | goals = 102 | top goal scorer = | player = | prevseason = | nextseason = [[2007–08 Serbian Cup|2007–08]] }} The '''2006–07 Serbian Cup season''' was the first staging of [[Serbia]]'s [[football (soccer)|football]] knockout competition. It was the first tournament that Serbia ever held as an independent football association. Montenegro also held its first independent cup tournament in the 2006–07 season. The predecessor competition was the [[Serbia and Montenegro Cup]] until that state dissolved. Heavy favorites [[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]] defeated [[FK Vojvodina|Vojvodina]] to win the tournament and become Serbia's first cup winner and later clinched the [[Serbian SuperLiga|Meridian SuperLiga]] title to claim its tenth domestic double. ==Individual awards== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- !Award !Recipient !Affiliation |- |[[Most Valuable Player]] |[[Nenad Milijaš]] |[[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]] |- |Golden Boot |[[Žarko Lazetić]] |[[FK Bežanija|Bežanija]] / [[FK Partizan|Partizan]] |- |Best Referee |Dejan Delević |[[Belgrade]] |} ==Round of 32== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- !Home team !Score !Away team |- |'''[[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]]''' |3–0 |[[FK Sevojno Užice|Sevojno]] |- |[[FK Timok|Timok]] |0–1 |'''[[FK Banat Zrenjanin|Banat]]''' |- |[[FK Jedinstvo Putevi|Jedinstvo Putevi]] |1–3 |'''[[FK Čukarički Stankom|Čukarički]]''' |- |'''[[OFK Mladenovac|Mladenovac]]''' |2–1 |[[FK Smederevo|Smederevo]] |- |[[FK Obilić|Obilić]] |0–3 |'''[[FK Vlasina|Vlasina]]''' |- |'''[[FK Vojvodina|Vojvodina]]''' |4–1 |[[FK BASK|BASK]] |- |'''[[FK Mokra Gora|Mokra Gora]]''' |1–1
4–3([[penalty shootout (football)|p]]) |[[FK Borac Čačak|Borac]] |- |'''[[FK Srem|Srem]]''' |1–0 |[[FK Rad|Rad]] |- |[[FK Spartak Subotica|Spartak]] |0–2 |'''[[FK Mladost Apatin|Mladost Apatin]]''' |- |[[FK Teleoptik|Teleoptik]] |2–2
4–5([[penalty shootout (football)|p]]) |'''[[FK Voždovac|Voždovac]]''' |- |'''[[FK Bežanija|Bežanija]]''' |4–0 |[[FK Mačva Šabac|Mačva]] |- |'''[[FK Napredak Kruševac|Napredak]]''' |3–0 |[[FK Javor Ivanjica|Javor Habitfarm]] |- |'''[[FK Radnički Niš|Radnički Niš]]''' |3–0 |[[FK Hajduk Kula|Hajduk Kula]] |- |[[FK Big Bull|Big Bull]] |0–4 |'''[[OFK Beograd]]''' |- |'''[[FK Partizan|Partizan]]''' |3–0 |[[FK ČSK Pivara|ČSK]] |- |[[FK Zemun|Zemun]] |3–5 |'''[[FK Radnički Pirot|Radnički Pirot]]''' |} ==Round of 16== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- !Home team !Score !Away team |- |'''[[FK Partizan|Partizan]]''' |2–0 |[[Srem]] |- |[[Mokra Gora]] |1–2 |'''[[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]]''' |- |'''[[FK Mladost Apatin|Mladost Apatin]]''' |2–0 |[[OFK Beograd]] |- |[[Mladenovac]] |0–1 |'''[[FK Vojvodina|Vojvodina]]''' |- |[[FK Vlasina|Vlasina]] |2–4 |'''[[FK Bežanija|Bežanija]]''' |- |'''[[FK Banat Zrenjanin|Banat]]''' |8–7 |[[FK Napredak Kruševac|Napredak]] |- |[[FK Voždovac|Voždovac]] |1–2 |'''[[FK Čukarički Stankom|Čukarički]]''' |- |'''[[FK Radnički Pirot|Radnički Pirot]]''' |3–1 |[[Radnički Niš]] |} ==Quarter finals== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- !Home team !Score !Away team |- |[[FK Radnički Pirot|Radnički Pirot]] |1–2 |'''[[FK Vojvodina|Vojvodina]]''' |- |'''[[FK Banat Zrenjanin|Banat]]''' |1–0 |[[FK Bežanija|Bežanija]] |- |[[FK Čukarički Stankom|Čukarički]] |0–2 |'''[[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]]''' |- |[[FK Mladost Apatin|Mladost Apatin]] |0–3 |'''[[FK Partizan|Partizan]]''' |} ==Semi finals== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- !Home team !Score !Away team |- |'''[[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]]''' |1–0 |[[FK Partizan|Partizan]] |- |'''[[FK Vojvodina|Vojvodina]]''' |1–0 |[[FK Banat Zrenjanin|Banat]] |} ==Final== The Final was held at [[Partizan Stadium|Partizan's Stadium]] on May 15, 2007 in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]]. The final pitted Serbian powerhouse [[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]] against the up-and-coming side [[FK Vojvodina]]. Vojvodina jumped out to the brighter start, with great attacking play from midfielder [[Milan Davidov]] running the show and wing-back [[Nikola Petković]] causing problems down the left. Striker [[Ranko Despotović]] came close in the 10th minute after a darting run by Petković luckily for Red Star their veteran defender [[Dušan Basta]] foiled a flowing move with a last-gasp tackle with keeper [[Ivan Ranđelović]] beaten. Red Star responded with a [[Nenad Milijaš]] free kick that almost crept in and [[Milan Purović]]`s close-range header before Koroman broke the deadlock on the hour with a crisp shot from the edge of the penalty box. Vojvodina were on the back foot in the second half and failed to muster a single shot on target as Davidov faded and talented [[Montenegrins (citizens)|Montenegrin]] playmaker [[Igor Burzanović]] ran their defence ragged at the other end. [[Dušan Đokić]] sealed the win with a delightful 85th-minute lob after a defence-splitting pass from Burzanović. "We couldn't break them down in the first half but our lads responded well after the halftime chat in the dressing room and we dedicate this victory to our fans," said Red Star's delighted coach [[Boško Djurovski]]. Koroman also praised the home section of the 25,000 crowd and said Red Star would now aim for success in Europe. "Our fans were like an extra man on the pitch again and we want to treat them to some [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] football next season." {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !width=35%|Home Club !width=15%|Score !width=35%|Visiting Club |- style="background:#f5faff;" |'''[[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]]'''
|'''2 – 0'''
|[[FK Vojvodina|Vojvodina]]
|- |'''Date''' | colspan="2" | May 15, 2007 |- style="background:#f5faff;" |'''Locale''' | colspan="2" | [[Partizan Stadium]], [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]] |- |'''Attendance''' | colspan="2" | 25,000 (cap. 32,887) |- style="background:#f5faff;" |'''Referee''' | colspan="2" | Dejan Delević (Belgrade) |- |'''[[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]]'''
(coach: [[Boško Đurovski]]) | colspan="2" | [[Ivan Ranđelović|Randjelović]], [[Dušan Basta|Basta]], [[Ibrahima Gueye (footballer, born 1978)|Gueye]], [[Đorđe Tutorić|Tutorić]], [[Dušan Anđelković|Andjelković]], [[Dejan Milovanović|Milovanović]], [[Segundo Castillo|Castillo]], [[Nenad Milijaš|Milijaš]], [[Milanko Rašković|Rašković]] (56' [[Igor Burzanović|Burzanović]]), [[Ognjen Koroman|Koroman]] (84' [[Nebojša Joksimović (footballer)|Joksimović]]), [[Milan Purović|Purović]] (75' [[Dušan Đokić|Đokić]]). |- style="background:#f5faff;" |'''[[FK Vojvodina|Vojvodina]]'''
(coach: [[Milovan Rajevac]]) | colspan="2" | [[Damir Kahriman|Kahriman]], [[Miodrag Stošić|Stošić]], [[Igor Đurić (Serbian footballer)|Đurić]], [[Nino Pekarić|Pekarić]], [[Nikola Petković|Petković]], [[Gojko Kačar|Kačar]] (75' [[Predrag Sikimić|Sikimić]]), [[Aleksandar Popović (footballer, born 1983)|Popović]], [[Vladimir Buač|Buač]] (65' [[Miodrag Pantelić|Pantelić]]), [[Dušan Tadić|Tadić]] (88' [[Goran Smiljanić|Smiljanić]]), [[Milan Davidov|Davidov]], [[Ranko Despotović|Despotović]]. |- |'''Notes''' | colspan="2" | '''Scorer:''' 1–0 Koroman 63', 2–0 Đokić 85' |} {{Serbian Cup}} {{2006-07 in European Football (UEFA)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2006-07 Serbian Cup}} [[Category:Serbian Cup]] [[Category:2006–07 domestic association football cups|Serbian Cup]] [[Category:2006–07 in Serbian football|Cup]] {{Europe-footy-competition-stub}} {{Serbia-sport-stub}}

{{TennisEventInfo|2009|SAT Bangkok Open| | date=March 16 – March 22 | edition=1st | location=[[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] | champs={{flagicon|GER}} [[Florian Mayer]] | champd={{flagicon|GBR}} [[Joshua Goodall]] / {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Joseph Sirianni]] }}
The '''2009 [[SAT Bangkok Open]]''' was a professional [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Tennis court#Hard courts|indoor hard courts]]. It was part of the [[2009 ATP Challenger Tour]]. It took place in [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] between 16 and 22 March 2009.
==Singles entrants== ===Seeds=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Nationality ! Player ! Ranking* ! Seeding |- | {{flag|GER}} | [[Andreas Beck (tennis)|Andreas Beck]] | 86 | 1 |- | {{flag|KOR}} | [[Lee Hyung-taik]] | 110 | 2 |- | {{flag|JPN}} | [[Go Soeda]] | 117 | 3 |- | {{flag|AUS}} | [[Chris Guccione (tennis)|Chris Guccione]] | 134 | 4 |- | {{flag|FRA}} | [[Mathieu Montcourt]] | 136 | 5 |- | {{flag|RUS}} | [[Michail Elgin]] | 138 | 6 |- | {{flag|GER}} | [[Daniel Brands]] | 148 | 7 |- | {{flag|IND}} | [[Somdev Devvarman]] | 150 | 8 |} *Rankings are as of March 9, 2009.
===Other entrants=== The following players received wildcards into the singles main draw: * {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Guillermo Coria]] * {{flagicon|BUL}} [[Grigor Dimitrov]] * {{flagicon|THA}} Peerakit Siributwong * {{flagicon|THA}} [[Kittipong Wachiramanowong]]
The following players received entry from the qualifying draw: * {{flagicon|IND}} [[Rohan Bopanna]] * {{flagicon|KOR}} [[Im Kyu-tae]] * {{flagicon|ISR}} [[Noam Okun]] * {{flagicon|USA}} [[Tim Smyczek]]
The following player received [[Glossary of tennis#Special Exempt|Special Exempt]] into the main draw: * {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Sergei Bubka (tennis)|Sergei Bubka]] * {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Takao Suzuki]]
==Champions== ===Men's singles=== {{main|2009 SAT Bangkok Open – Singles}} {{flagicon|GER}} '''[[Florian Mayer]]''' def. {{flagicon|THA}} [[Danai Udomchoke]], 7–5, 6–2
===Men's doubles=== {{main|2009 SAT Bangkok Open – Doubles}} {{flagicon|GBR}} '''[[Joshua Goodall]]''' / {{flagicon|AUS}} '''[[Joseph Sirianni]]''' def. {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Mikhail Elgin]] / {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Alexander Kudryavtsev]], 6–3, 6–1
==External links== *[http://www.protennislive.com/posting/2009/5047/x.pdf 2009 Draws]
{{DEFAULTSORT:2009 Sat Bangkok Open}} [[Category:2009 ATP Challenger Tour|SAT Bangkok Open]] [[Category:SAT Bangkok Open]]

page.title: 2015 World Wheelchair Curling Championship – Qualification Event

revision.comment: Fix caps in section header and other minor fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]

{{infobox curling | Name = 2015 World Wheelchair Curling Championship
Qualification Event | Logo = | Size = | Host city = [[Lillehammer]], [[Norway]] | Arena = [[Lillehammer Curling Club]] | Dates = November 1–6, 2014 | Winner = '''{{NOR}}''' | Curling club = none | Skip = [[Rune Lorentsen]] | Third = [[Jostein Stordahl]] | Second = [[Sissel Løchen]] | Lead = [[Terge Rafdal]] | Alternate = [[Ole Fredrik Syversen]] | Coach = [[Per Andreassen]] | Finalist = {{GER}} ([[Jens Jäger]]) }} The '''qualification event''' of the '''[[2015 World Wheelchair Curling Championship]]''' was held from November 1 to 6, 2014 at the [[Lillehammer Curling Club]] in [[Lillehammer]], [[Norway]].{{cite web|url=http://worldcurling.org/world-curling-federation-announce-hosts-for-2014-15-events|title=World Curling Federation announce hosts for 2014-15 events|date=4 April 2014|publisher=[[World Curling Federation]]|accessdate=14 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://wwhcc2015.curlingevents.com/world-wheelchair-qualification-event-begins-november-1|title=World Wheelchair Curling Qualification event begins November 1|date=1 November 2014|publisher=[[World Curling Federation]]|accessdate=3 November 2014}} The qualification event was open to any [[World Curling Federation]] member nation not already qualified for the World Championship. The event's two top finishers, Norway and Germany, will join the top eight finishers from the last World Wheelchair Curling Championship at this season's event in Lohja, Finland. This event would have marked the first appearance of Israel at an international wheelchair curling event, but Israel was deemed ineligible to play due to an inability to meet classification criteria. ==Teams== {| class="wikitable" |- !width=200|{{BUL}} !width=200|{{CZE}} !width=200|{{DEN}} !width=200|{{GER}} |- | '''Skip:''' [[Ivan Shopov (curler)|Ivan Shopov]]

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Aitken University Centre | nickname = | image = Aitken Centre.jpg | image_caption = Interior of the Aitken Centre | location = 20 MacKay Drive
[[Fredericton]], [[New Brunswick]]
E3B 5A3 | coordinates = {{coord|45.941959|-66.641884|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1976 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | owner = [[University of New Brunswick]] | operator = | surface = 200' X 90' | construction_cost = | contractor = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[UNB Varsity Reds]] ([[Atlantic University Sport|AUS]]) 1976-present
[[Fredericton Express]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) 1981-1988
[[Fredericton Canadiens]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) 1990-1999 | seating_capacity = 3,278 (seated, hockey)
4,258 (Concerts) }} The '''Aitken University Centre''' is located on the campus of the [[University of New Brunswick]] in [[Fredericton]], [[New Brunswick]]. Constructed in 1976, it is the home of the [[UNB Varsity Reds]] hockey and hosted UNB basketball games until the construction of the Richard J. Currie Center in 2011. The arena hosted the [[University Cup]] in 2003, 2004, 2011, and 2012. The Aitken Centre was also the venue for the 2006 CIS Women's basketball championships, and the 2007 and 2008 CIS Women's volleyball championships. The arena's capacity is 3,278 for ice events and 4,258 for concerts. ==Other uses== [[File:Aitken University Centre, University of New Brunswick.jpg|thumb|Aitken University Centre, UNB]] The Aitken Centre was home to the [[American Hockey League]]'s [[Fredericton Express]] (1981-1988) and [[Fredericton Canadiens]] (1990-1999). The arena was used as a set during the filming of the television miniseries ''[[Canada Russia '72]]''. It stood in for the [[Montreal Forum]], [[Maple Leaf Gardens]] and [[Luzhniki Palace of Sports]]. ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070404080515/http://www.aitkencentre.unb.ca/ Aitken University Centre Official Site] [[Category:University of New Brunswick]] [[Category:Sports venues in New Brunswick]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Fredericton]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in New Brunswick]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Canada]] [[Category:Fredericton Canadiens]] [[Category:Music venues in New Brunswick]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1976]] [[Category:Sport in Fredericton]] [[Category:1976 establishments in New Brunswick]] {{canada-icehockey-venue-stub}}

{{coord|40.2032|-74.7609|display=title}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Arm & Hammer Park | nickname = | image = [[File:Arm & Hammer Park.png]]
[[Image:Waterfront Park.jpg|right|225px|Waterfront Park]] | location = One Thunder Road
[[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton, NJ]], 08611 | broke_ground = September 29, 1993{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mvFmZ2kPiBAC&pg=PA10&dq=plumeri+trenton&hl=en&ei=J14-TNrgN8Oclge6_cz4BQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=plumeri%20&f=false|title=Baseball in Trenton|publisher=[[Arcadia Publishing]]|first=Tom|last=McCarthy|year=2003|ISBN=0-7385-1310-5}} | opened = May 9, 1994 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Mercer County, New Jersey|Mercer County]] | operator = [[Trenton Thunder|Garden State Baseball, LP]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]16.2 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|16200000|1994}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Clarke & Caton
Faridy Thorne Fraytak P. C.{{cite web |title=Waterfront Park|first=Graham|last=Knight|url=http://www.baseballpilgrimages.com/minors/trenton.html|work=Baseball Pilgrimages|date=July 7, 2012|accessdate=February 23, 2014}} | project_manager = Burris Construction Company- Phase 2 | structural engineer = Harrison-Hamnett, P.C.{{cite web |title=Stadium Projects|url=http://www.hhpccse.com/StadiumProjects--.pdf |accessdate=September 24, 2011}} | services engineer = Paulus, Sokolowski & Sartor, LLC.{{cite web|title=Entertainment |url=http://www.psands.com/markets/ent.php |publisher=Paulus, Sokolowski & Sartor, LLC |accessdate=September 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111024160811/http://www.psands.com/markets/ent.php |archivedate=October 24, 2011 }} | general_contractor = V.J. Scozzari & Sons Inc.- Phase 1 | former_names = Mercer County Waterfront Park (1994–2012) | tenants = [[Trenton Thunder]] ([[Eastern League (baseball)|EL]]) (1994–Present) | seating_capacity = 6,150{{cite news |title=Changes to Trenton's Waterfront Park Make It More Wheelchair Friendly|first=Samantha|last=Costa|url=http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2012/03/changes_to_trentons_waterfront.html|newspaper=[[The Times (Trenton)]]|date=March 22, 2012|accessdate=May 26, 2014}} | dimensions = Left Field: {{convert|330|ft|m}}
Center Field: {{convert|407|ft|m}}
Right Field: {{convert|330|ft|m}} }} '''Arm & Hammer Park''', also known as '''Mercer County Waterfront Park''', is a venue located in [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]], [[New Jersey]]. It is the home [[baseball park]] for the [[Trenton Thunder]], a Double-A level [[Minor League Baseball]] team of the [[Eastern League (baseball)|Eastern League]]. The official [[seating capacity]] is 6,150. ==History== The park was built for the 1994 season, although it opened several weeks late due to a rough winter that hampered construction. The sod also was unable to take properly that season, and the field did not properly drain, leading to rainouts on evenings where the sun had been out since noon. The drainage problem was fixed in 1995. The stadium's original name was "Mercer County Waterfront Park" when it opened in 1994. "Samuel J. Plumeri, Sr. Field" was added to the original name in 1999 by Trenton Thunder owner, [[Joe Plumeri]] (Chairman and CEO of [[Willis Group Holdings]]). Samuel J. Plumeri, Sr. was Joe Plumeri's father. In November 2012, the New Jersey-based [[Arm & Hammer (brand)|Arm & Hammer]] purchased the ballpark's naming rights and will maintain its sponsorship through 2032.{{cite news |title=Mercer County Waterfront Park Baseball Venue to Be Renamed Arm & Hammer Park|first=Emily|last=Brill|url=http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2012/11/mercer_county_waterfront_park.html|newspaper=[[The Times (Trenton)]]|date=November 14, 2012|accessdate=February 23, 2014}} In June 2014, the park hosted the first-ever, gold– and bronze–medal games in baseball for the [[Special Olympics USA#2014 Games|Special Olympics USA National Games]].{{cite web|title=Special Olympics baseball games debut at Trenton Thunder ballpark|first=Benjamin|last=Teicher|date=June 19, 2014|publisher=[[Asbury Park Press]]|url=http://www.app.com/story/sports/2014/06/19/special-olympics-baseball-games-debut-trenton-thunder-ballpark/11005217/|accessdate=2014-06-21}}{{cite web|title=New Jersey Wins Special Olympics Gold At ARM & HAMMER Park|date=June 20, 2014|publisher=[[Trenton Thunder]]|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20140620&content_id=80731854&fext=.jsp&vkey=news_t567&sid=t567|accessdate=2014-06-21|quote=Team New Jersey captured the Gold Medal in the Special Olympics USA Games Inaugural Baseball Finals. Team Rhode Island earned the Silver Medal, Team Delaware earned Bronze and Team Alabama finished in fourth.}} In 2018, it hosted the Eastern League All-Star Game.{{cite web|title=Trenton To Host 2018 All-Star Game|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20160712&content_id=189374878&fext=.jsp&vkey=news_milb|website=MiLB.com|publisher=Minor League Baseball|accessdate=30 January 2017}} ===Attendance records=== Arm & Hammer Park set a record for game attendance on July 3, 2011, when the Thunder played the [[Altoona Curve]]. The game had the fortune of falling on the [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] holiday weekend, as well as featuring an injury rehabilitation appearance by [[Derek Jeter]] of the [[New York Yankees]]. The official attendance for the game was 9,212.{{cite news |title=Jeter Finishes Rehab; Set to Rejoin Yankees|first=Dan|last=Tomasino|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/sports/yankees/captain_america_HqTEhedh2YHh9BYk1DTaOO|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|date=July 4, 2011|accessdate=July 5, 2011}} When [[Alex Rodriguez]] played two games on back-to-back nights in August 2013, the official attendance was reported at 8,080 and 8,113, respectively.{{cite web |title=A-Rod Makes Strides As Rehab Stint Ends|first=David|last=Wilson|url=http://newyork.yankees.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20130803&content_id=55784728&vkey=news_nyy&c_id=nyy|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=August 3, 2013|accessdate=August 3, 2013}} ==Features== While the outfield in left and center field is covered with advertising signs that obscure views of [[New Jersey Route 29|Route 29]] and nearby houses, the right field fence was kept as a short structure so that fans could see the [[Delaware River]] and [[Pennsylvania]] beyond. The river is also an inviting target for left-handed sluggers, several of whom have deposited baseballs into the water. Similar to [[Great American Ball Park]] and its river border with [[Kentucky]], Arm & Hammer Park also holds the possibility of having someone "hit one out of the state" since the middle of the Delaware River is the border with Pennsylvania. On June 7, 1994, [[Tony Clark]] became the first player to hit a fair ball into the Delaware.{{cite news|last1=Frankllin|first1=Paul|title=Tony Clark was a huge hit with the Trenton Thunder|url=http://www.nj.com/times-sports/index.ssf/2013/04/tony_clark_was_a_huge_hit_with.html|accessdate=16 January 2018|work=NJ.com|date=April 10, 2013}} The stadium anchors an area of rejuvenation in Trenton that also includes office buildings, nightclubs, and the [[CURE Insurance Arena]], several blocks away, for [[ice hockey]], [[basketball]] and [[arena football]]. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Arm & Hammer Park}} *[http://web.minorleaguebaseball.com/team1/page.jsp?ymd=20101029&content_id=15897034&vkey=team1_t567&fext=.jsp&sid=t567 Trenton Thunder] *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2002/Trenton/Trenton.htm Arm & Hammer Park Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] {{Trenton Thunder}} {{Eastern League ballparks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arm and Hammer Park}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Trenton, New Jersey]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Trenton, New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports in Trenton, New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues in the New York metropolitan area]] [[Category:1994 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] [[Category:Trenton Thunder]]
