'''Left Center Field:''' {{convert|375|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Center Field:''' {{convert|400|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Right Center Field:''' {{convert|375|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Right Field:''' {{convert|330|ft|m|sp=us}} | tenants = [[Rhode Island Rams baseball]] ([[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|D1]] [[Atlantic 10 Conference|A-10]]) (1966-present) }} '''Bill Beck Field''' is a [[baseball]] venue located on the campus of the [[University of Rhode Island]] in [[Kingston, Rhode Island]], United States. It is home to the [[Rhode Island Rams baseball]] team, a member of the [[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Atlantic 10 Conference]]. The field was built in 1966 and is named after former Rams [[college baseball|baseball]] and [[college football|football]] coach [[Bill Beck]].[http://www.gorhody.com/facilities/uri-facilities.html Facilities] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5yyEYca4s?url=http://www.gorhody.com/facilities/uri-facilities.html |date=2011-05-26 }} at gorhody.com, URL accessed May 16, 2010. It has a capacity of 1,000 spectators.{{cite web |title=2012 Rhode Island Baseball Quick Facts |url=http://www.gorhody.com/sports/m-basebl/2011-12/files/2012_URI_baseball_quick_facts.pdf |work=GoRhody.com |publisher=Rhode Island Sports Information |accessdate=19 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XQHwhe2?url=http://www.gorhody.com/sports/m-basebl/2011-12/files/2012_URI_baseball_quick_facts.pdf |archivedate=2012-06-19 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The field is located behind Mackal Field House, the home venue of Rhode Island's men's and women's indoor track & field teams.{{cite web |title=Bill Beck Field |url=http://thingstodo.providencejournal.com/south_kingstown_ri/venues/show/1107925-bill-beck-field |work=ProvidenceJournal.com |accessdate=19 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XQS7OJJ?url=http://thingstodo.providencejournal.com/south_kingstown_ri/venues/show/1107925-bill-beck-field |archivedate=2012-06-19 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Renovations== In 2000, extensive renovations to the field began. The playing surface was leveled and resodded, and a new sprinkler system was added. In 2001, the field's [[Dugout (baseball)|dugout]]s were replaced. In 2002, an electronic scoreboard was installed, two [[batting cage]]s were added down the right field line, and the field's fencing was replaced. Later, matching batting cages were added down the left field line. In 2007, a [[USD|$]]1 million donation to the baseball program led to $1.4 million renovations on Bill Beck Field. Completed in time for the 2009 season, a new backstop, scoreboard, fencing, and bullpens were constructed. Also, a new [[FieldTurf]] surface was installed. ==Other uses== In 2013, the field was used for the final game of the [[2013 America East Conference Baseball Tournament|America East Tournament]], after rain and scheduling conflicts forced [[America East Conference]] officials to move the game from its scheduled venue, [[Edward A. LeLacheur Park]] in [[Lowell, Massachusetts]]. In the game, [[Binghamton Bearcats baseball|Binghamton]] defeated [[Maine Black Bears baseball|Maine]], 4-0.{{cite web |title=Baseball Championship Game Postponed Until Sunday |url=http://www.bubearcats.com/index.php/news/show/baseball_and_maine_postponed_until_sunday |work=BUBearcats.com |publisher=Binghamton Sports Information |accessdate=August 24, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6J7gJo4iW?url=http://www.bubearcats.com/index.php/news/show/baseball_and_maine_postponed_until_sunday |archivedate=August 24, 2013 |date=May 25, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web |last=Jordan |first=Glenn |title=College Baseball: Maine Falls in America East Championship |url=http://www.onlinesentinel.com/sports/COLLEGE-BASEBALL-Maine-falls-in-America-East-championship.html |work=OnlineSentinel.com |publisher=Morning Sentinel |accessdate=August 24, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6J7gOIjC5?url=http://www.onlinesentinel.com/sports/COLLEGE-BASEBALL-Maine-falls-in-America-East-championship.html |archivedate=August 24, 2013 |location=Waterville, ME, USA |date=May 26, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The venue is also used for other amateur tournaments.{{cite web |title=Rhode Island Sports Group Summer Baseball |url=http://risgsummerbaseball.com/ |accessdate=August 24, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6J7ge8tcs?url=http://risgsummerbaseball.com/ |archivedate=August 24, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{University of Rhode Island}} {{Atlantic 10 Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Rhode Island NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Rhode Island]] [[Category:Rhode Island Rams baseball]] [[Category:1966 establishments in Rhode Island]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Olympic organisations to [[:Category:Olympic organizations]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox high court |court_name = Court of Arbitration for Sport |native_name = {{fr}} Tribunal arbitral du sport |image = Court of Arbitration for Sport - Lausanne 2.jpg |imagesize = |caption = Headquarters, in [[Lausanne]] ([[Switzerland]]). |motto = |established = 1984[http://www.tas-cas.org/en/general-information/history-of-the-cas.html History of the Court of Arbitration for Sport], official website of the Court of Arbitration for Sport (page visited on 5 May 2016). |dissolved = |country = [[Switzerland]] |location = [[Lausanne]] |coordinates = |type = |authority = [[International Olympic Committee]] ([[Olympic Charter]]) |appeals = [[Federal Supreme Court of Switzerland]] |terms = |positions = |budget = |website = [http://www.tas-cas.org/en www.tas-cas.org] | chiefjudgetitle = President | chiefjudgename = [[John Coates (sports administrator)|John Coates]] | termstart = 2011 }} [[File:Court of Arbitration for Sport - Lausanne.jpg|thumb|The entrance of the headquarters of the Court of Arbitration for Sport, in [[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]].]] [[File:Court of Arbitration for Sport, door, 2012 (cropped).jpg|thumb|]] The '''Court of Arbitration for Sport''' ('''CAS'''; {{lang-fr|Tribunal arbitral du sport}}, TAS) is an international [[quasi-judicial body]] established to settle disputes related to sport through [[arbitration]]. Its headquarters are in [[Lausanne]] (Switzerland) and its courts are located in [[New York City]], [[Sydney]] and [[Lausanne]]. Temporary courts are established in current [[Olympic host cities]]. ==Jurisdiction and appeals== Generally speaking, a dispute may be submitted to the CAS only if there is an arbitration agreement between the parties which specifies recourse to the CAS. However, according to rule 61 of the Olympic Charter, all disputes in connection with the Olympic Games can only be submitted to CAS,[[International Olympic Committee]]: [http://www.olympic.org/Documents/olympic_charter_en.pdf Olympic Charter] and all Olympic [[List of international sport federations|International Federations]] (IF) have recognised the jurisdiction of CAS for at least some disputes.Richard H. McLaren, [http://scholarship.law.marquette.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1482&context=sportslaw Twenty-Five Years of the Court of Arbitration for Sport: A Look in the Rear-View Mirror, 20 Marq. Sports L. Rev. 305] (2010) Through compliance with the 2009 [[World Anti-Doping Agency|World Anti-Doping Code]], all signatories, including all Olympic International Federations and [[National Olympic Committee]]s, have recognised the jurisdiction of CAS for [[Doping in sport|anti-doping rule violations]].[[World Anti-Doping Agency]]: [http://www.wada-ama.org/rtecontent/document/code_v2009_en.pdf 2009 World Anti-Doping Code] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120824032644/http://www.wada-ama.org/rtecontent/document/code_v2009_En.pdf |date=24 August 2012 }}Hilary Findlay and Marcus F. Mazzucco: [https://www.academia.edu/1190383/The_Supervisory_Role_of_the_Court_of_Arbitration_for_Sport_in_Regulating_the_International_Sport_System The Supervisory Role of the Court of Arbitration for Sport in Regulating the International Sport System] Starting in 2016, an anti-doping division of CAS judges doping cases at the Olympic Games, replacing the IOC disciplinary commission.Karolos Grohman: [http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-olympics-doping-cas-idUKKCN0W35IA CAS to take over doping cases at Olympics] Accessed 18 June 2016. These decisions can be appealed to CAS's ad hoc court in the Olympic host city or, if the ad hoc court is no longer available, to the permanent CAS.Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Arbitration_Rules_for_the_Anti-doping_Division__final_.pdf Arbitration Rules Applicable to the CAS Anti-doping division] Accessed 18 June 2016. The inaugural anti-doping division handled eight cases, of which seven were doping cases within its jurisdiction.Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Report_on_the_activities_of_the_CAS_Divisions_at_the_2016_Rio_Olympic_Games__short_version__FINAL.pdf Report on the activities of the CAS Divisions at the 2016 Rio Olympic Games] Accessed 31 August 2016 As a Swiss arbitration organization, decisions of the CAS can be appealed to the [[Federal Supreme Court of Switzerland]].Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Media20Release20FC20Sion.pdf Media release 23 July 2012] Appeals of arbitration decisions are generally not successful,CAS Bulletin 2011/2 [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Bulletin202_2011.pdf Appeals against Arbitral Awards by the CAS] by Stephan Netzle and no evaluation of the merits is taking place and the evaluation is mainly based on whether procedural requirements have been met, and whether the award is incompatible with [[public policy]]. {{As of|2012|3}} there have been seven successful appeals. Six of the upheld appeals were procedural in nature, and only once has the Federal Supreme Court overruled a CAS decision on the merits of the case. This was in the case of [[Matuzalém]], a Brazilian football player.Roy Levy: [http://www.probst-law.ch/bilder/The-International-Sports-Law-Journal-2012.pdf Swiss Federal Tribunal overrules CAS award in a landmark decision: FIFA vs Matuzalem] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325190508/http://www.probst-law.ch/bilder/The-International-Sports-Law-Journal-2012.pdf |date=25 March 2014 }} The [[Federal Court of Justice of Germany]] ruled against the German speed-skater [[Claudia Pechstein]], recognising a lack of jurisdiction to revisit her case. The Federal Court ruled that CAS met the requirements of a court of arbitration according to German law, and that CAS's independence from the parties was secured by the method of selecting arbitrators and the possibility to appeal to the Swiss Federal Tribunal.Christian Keidel: [http://www.lawinsport.com/sports-law-news/item/german-federal-tribunal-rejects-claudia-pechstein-s-claim-for-damages-against-international-skating-union-isu German Federal Tribunal rejects Claudia Pechstein’s claim for damages against International Skating Union (ISU)] Accessed 17 June 2016.CAS hosted: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Pechstein___ISU_translation_ENG_final.pdf English translation of German Federal Tribunal decision] ==History== With the intermixing of [[sports and politics]], the body was originally conceived by [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) president [[Juan Antonio Samaranch]] to deal with disputes arising during the Olympics. It was established as part of the IOC in [[1984 in sports|1984]]. In 1992, the case of ''Gundel v. La Fédération Equestre Internationale'' was decided by the CAS, and then appealed to the [[Federal Supreme Court of Switzerland]], challenging CAS impartiality. The Swiss court ruled that the CAS was a true court of [[arbitration]] but drew attention to the numerous links between the CAS and the IOC.[http://www.polyreg.ch/bgepub/Band_119_1993/BGE_119_II_271.html BGE 119 II 271] (Gundel v La Fédération Equestre Internationale) In response, the CAS underwent reforms to make itself more independent of the IOC, both organizationally and financially. The biggest change resulting from this reform was the creation of an "International Council of Arbitration for Sport" (ICAS) to look after the running and financing of the CAS, thereby taking the place of the IOC. {{As of|2004}}, most recent cases that were considered by the CAS dealt with transfer disputes within professional [[association football]] or with [[use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport|doping]]. The Court of Arbitration for Sport is planning to move its headquarters from the Château de Béthusy to the south part of the [[Palais de Beaulieu]] (both in [[Lausanne]]).Aïna Skjellaug, [http://www.letemps.ch/suisse/2016/05/18/prive-tour-taoua-beaulieu-presente-plan-b "Privé de sa tour Taoua, Beaulieu présente son plan B"], ''[[Le Temps]]'', Wednesday 18 May 2016 (page visited on 18 May 2016). ==CAS Board== {| border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" |- bgcolor="#006400" align="center" span style="color:white" ! Designation !! Name !! Country |- | '''CAS President''' || [[John Coates (sports administrator)|John D. Coates]] || {{AUS}} |- |rowspan=2| '''CAS Vice-Presidents || [[Michael Lenard]] || {{USA}} |- | Ms. [[Tjasa Andrée-Prosenc]] || {{SLO}} |- | '''President of CAS Ordinary Division''' || Ms. [[Carole Malinvaud]] || {{FRA}} |- | '''President of Appeals Arbitration Division''' || Ms. [[Corinne Schmidhauser]] || {{SUI}} |- | '''CAS Secretary General''' || [[Matthieu Reeb]] || {{SUI}} |} ==CAS Members== {| border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" |- bgcolor="#006400" align="center" span style="color:white" ! S. No. !! Name !! Country |- | 1. || Dr. [[Abdullah Al Hayyan]] || {{KUW}} |- | 2. || Ms. [[Tjasa Andrée-Prosenc]] || {{SLO}} |- | 3. || [[Patrick Baumann (basketball)|Patrick Baumann]] || {{SUI}} |- | 4. || [[Scott Blackmun]] || {{USA}} |- | 5. || Ms. [[Alexandra Brilliantova]] || {{RUS}} |- | 6. || [[Miguel Cardenal Carro]] || {{ESP}} |- | 7. || [[John Coates (sports administrator)|John D. Coates]] || {{AUS}} |- | 8. || Ms. [[Moya Dodd]] || {{AUS}} |- | 9. || H. E. Judge [[Nabil Elaraby]] || {{EGY}} |- | 10. || [[Ivo Eusebio]] || {{SUI}} |- | 11. || [[Michael Lenard]] || {{USA}} |- | 12. || Ms. [[Carole Malinvaud]] || {{FRA}} |- | 13. || Justice [[Yvonne Mokgoro]] || {{RSA}} |- | 14. || Judge [[Ellen Gracie Northfleet]] || {{BRA}} |- | 15. || [[Göran Petersson]] || {{SWE}} |- | 16. || [[Dick Pound|Richard William Duncan Pound]] || {{CAN}} |- | 17. || Ms. [[Corinne Schmidhauser]] || {{SUI}} |- | 18. || Ms. [[Tricia C.M. Smith]] || {{CAN}} |- | 19. || Ms. [[Wilhelmina Thomassen]] || {{NED}} |- | 20. || Judge [[Hanqin Xue]] || {{NED}} |- | 21. || [[Matthieu Reeb]] || {{SUI}} |} ==Jurisprudence examples of note== ===Doping=== * In March 2011, the CAS decided its first case on [[biological passport|athlete biological passports]] (ABP) when it suspended two Italian cyclists, [[Franco Pellizotti]] and [[Pietro Caucchioli]], for two years based on evidence from their blood profiles.[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/09/sports/cycling/09cycling.html?_r=1 Court Upholds Cyclist's Ban Based on Biological Passport] ''New York Times''. Retrieved 24 March 2013
Prior to that, the case of skater [[Claudia Pechstein]] had been decided (2009/A/1912 & 1913) on similar grounds.CAS Bulletin 2011/2 [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Bulletin202_2011.pdf The Athlete Biological Passport Program] by Despina Mavromati Writing in the 2011/2 CAS Bulletin regarding the institution of the ABP program, CAS Counsel Despina Mavromati differentiated between the two types of cases and wrote:
It is noteworthy that CAS had already issued an award suspending an athlete based on the longitudinal profiling of the biological markers before the adoption of the ABP by the IFs [international federations]: in CAS 2009/A/1912 & 1913 [Pechstein], the Panel suspended an Olympic athlete after the biological data showed irregular blood values. According to CAS, those abnormal values were not caused by an error occurred in a laboratory, as the athlete asserted, but due to the banned manipulation of the athlete’s blood. The essential difference between ABP judgments and the CAS 2009/A/1912 & 1913 consists in that in the latter case the athlete’s blood data was drawn from a sample the athlete gave at the federations championships and therefore not from data gathered by an official systematic program run by the athlete’s union.
* In 2001, the court decided the case of [[Andreea Răducan]] versus [[International Olympic Committee]]. This was a controversial anti-doping case, where it was fairly clear the athlete received cold and flu tablets from her doctor. This resulted in a positive urine test, with the court concluding: "The Panel is aware of the impact its decision will have on a fine, young, elite athlete. It finds, in balancing the interests of Miss Raducan with the commitment of the Olympic Movement to drugfree sport, the Anti-Doping Code must be enforced without compromise.”''Essentials of Sport Law'', by Glenn M. Wong, Fourth Edition, Note 5.3.9 * The court is reluctant to overturn [[Referee|field of play decisions]], though it may do so in cases where there is clear evidence that the officials acted in [[bad faith]] or with [[arbitrariness]].Court of Arbitration for Sport:[http://www.centrostudisport.it/PDF/TAS_CAS_ULTIMO/105.pdf CAS 2012/A/2731 ''BOC & BTC & Márcio W. Ferreira v/ WTF & COM & FMT & Damian A.Villa Valadez''] See §104 in particular. In CAS 2010/A/2090, the CAS Panel explained that the reason for this is not a matter of jurisdiction, but of arbitral self-restraint.Aino-Kaisa Saarinen; Finnish Ski Association (FSA) vs Fédération Internationale de Ski (FIS) [http://jurisprudence.tas-cas.org/Shared%20Documents/2090.pdf CAS/2010/A/2090] * In October 2011, in a case affecting the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], the court declared that a part of the [[Olympic Charter]] violated the World Anti-doping Code.USOC vs IOC [http://jurisprudence.tas-cas.org/Shared%20Documents/2422.pdf CAS/2011/O/2422] The "Osaka rule" therein had prevented athletes suspended for at least six months for anti-doping rule violations from competing at the Olympic Games following the suspension's expiration. The court later re-affirmed this decision, when it struck down a long-standing by-law of the [[British Olympic Association]] (BOA) preventing the selection of athletes sanctioned for doping.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/17853070 |title=London 2012: Dwain Chambers eligible after court ruling |work=BBC Sport |date=30 April 2012 |accessdate=5 August 2012}}BOA vs WADA [http://jurisprudence.tas-cas.org/Shared%20Documents/2658.pdf CAS/2011/A/2658] Both the IOC and BOA have responded by campaigning for adding a similar rule at the next update of the Code, which will be in effect by the [[2016 Summer Olympics]].{{By whom|date=July 2016}} *In July 2016 the CAS confirmed that the [[Russian Olympic Committee]] (ROC) could not enter track and field athletes for the [[2016 Summer Olympics]], with the exception of those cleared by the [[IAAF]] under the new competition rules regarding "neutral athletes". As the [[IOC]] was not a party to the case, the panel found it lacked jurisdiction to decide on whether the IOC could allow such cleared athletes to represent [[Russia at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Russia]], allow them to compete [[Independent Olympic Athletes at the 2016 Summer Olympics|independently]], or refuse their participation entirely.Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Media_Release_4684_210716.pdf CAS rejects the claims/appeal of the Russian Olympic Committee and 68 Russian athletes] Accessed 25 July 2016. The claimants disputed the validity and enforceability of IAAF Competition rule 22.1(a), regarding the suspension of the national federation ([[All-Russia Athletic Federation|RusAF, formerly ARAF]]), and rule 22.1A, regarding the eligibility of athletes from suspended federations. The panel found that neither rule could be construed as sanctions, and for this and other reasons they were consistent with the World Anti-Doping Code. The panels commented on the futility of the challenge to the new rule 22.1A, noting that as the rule provided athletes from Russia a new route to participation a successful challenge would lead to the exclusion of athletes eligible under the rule, not the inclusion of other athletes. The panel decided against evaluating whether the principle of [[estoppel]] applies to sporting disputes, as it found the claims in this case would have failed.Court of Arbitration for Sports: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Award_4684__internet_.pdf ROC ''et al.'' v. IAAF] Accessed 4 November 2016. At the same time, in a separate decision, the panel rejected the appeals of 67 Russian athletes against the decisions of the IAAF denying their applications to appear as "neutral athletes" at the 2016 Summer Olympics. [[Darya Klishina]] was the only Russian athlete cleared by both the IAAF and the IOC, but the IAAF declared her ineligible on 12 August based on new information. On 15 August the CAS ad hoc court upheld Klishina's appeal.Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Media_Release__English__Klishina_final.pdf Athletics: The application filed by Darya Klishina (Russia) is upheld by the CAS] Accessed 15 August 2016.{{cite news|title=Russia's sole athlete Darya Klishina cleared to compete after appeal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/aug/15/russias-darya-klishina-to-compete-after-appeal|work=The Guardian|accessdate=15 August 2016}} *The [[International Paralympic Committee]] (IPC) decided to ban [[Russia at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|Russia]] from the [[2016 Summer Paralympics]] due to the findings of the McLaren report. The appeal of the [[Russian Paralympic Committee]] (RPC) against the ban was dismissed by the CAS on 23 August. The court found that the suspension had a basis in the IPC rules, and stated that it "was proportionate in the circumstances". The panel noted that it had made no decision regarding the rights of individual athletes.Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Media_Release_RPC_IPC.pdf CAS dismisses the appeal filed by the Russian Paralympic Committee] Accessed 23 August 2016{{cite news|title=Rio Paralympics 2016: Russia banned after losing appeal|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/disability-sport/37165427|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=23 August 2016}} In its reasoned decision the panel elaborated on this point, stating that adverse consequences for the athletes represented by the RPC was not a reason to absolve the organisation from its legal responsibilities. The panel dismissed the claim that the IOC decision should have influenced the IPC decision, noting that the organisations have separate charters and rules. As the IPC also acts as an IF the court referred to the case between the RWF and the IWF where the CAS upheld a similar suspension.Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Award_4745_Final.pdf RPC v. IPC] (The sections referred to are from paragraph 79 onwards). Accessed 31 August 2016. *In late 2017 the IOC disqualified a large number of Russian athletes' results from the [[2014 Winter Olympics]]. The athletes were also given life-time bans from future editions of the games. CAS registered 42 appeals, of which 39 were decided before the [[2018 Winter Olympics]]. For 28 athletes the panel found that the evidence presented by the IOC was not sufficient to establish rule violations. In the 11 remaining cases the disqualifications were upheld, but the ban was limited to the 2018 Games. The panel made clear that its mandate was limited to the individual cases. The case does not affect the status of [[Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Russian athletes]] participating in PyongChang.{{citeweb|url=http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Media_Release__decision_RUS_IOC_.pdf|title=The Court of Arbitration for Sports (CAS) issues its decision in the matter of 39 Russian athletes v/ the IOC|author=Court of Arbitration for Sports|date=1 February 2018|accessdate=1 February 2018}}{{citenews|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/winter-olympics/42901377|title=Winter Olympics 2018: Court overturns life bans given to Russian athletes|publisher=BBC|date=1 February 2018|accessdate=1 February 2018}} The IOC expressed its regret with the decision regarding the 28 athletes whose appeals were fully upheld, stating that the level of proof required was inconsistent with earlier CAS decisions. The IOC also stated that the sanctions being lifted was not a sufficient reason for inviting the 28 athletes to compete at the 2018 Games. The IOC said it would consider its options after receiving the reasoned decision.{{citeweb|url=https://www.olympic.org/news/ioc-statement-on-cas-decision|title=IOC Statement on CAS decision|author=International Olympic Committee|date=1 February 2018|accessdate=1 February 2018}} In response to the ruling by the CAS, [[Jim Walden (lawyer)|Jim Walden]], the attorney representing [[Grigory Rodchenkov|Dr. Grigory Rodchenkov]], stated that the ruling made a "mockery"of the sanctions against Russia.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/democracy-post/wp/2018/02/05/in-the-latest-chapter-of-the-doping-scandal-russia-gets-a-pass/|title=Opinion {{!}} In the latest chapter of the doping scandal, Russia gets a pass|last=Walden|first=Jim|date=2018-02-05|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-02-07|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} * In 2018, the World Anti-Doping Agency appealed to the CAS after FIFA reduced a suspension of Peruvian national team captain [[Paolo Guerrero]]. Guerrero had tested positive for cocaine after a World Cup qualifier against Argentina after ingesting a tea containing the substance. Guerrero was initially suspended for a total of 12 months, but this was later halved by FIFA's appeal committee. WADA in turn appealed to the CAS and they imposed the 14 month ban in May 2018 which will cause Guerrero to miss the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]. The CAS confirmed the existence of an anti-doping rule violation (ADRV), but also accepted that Guerrero was not trying to enhance his performance by ingesting the substance. The panel had considered that the player did bear some fault or negligence, even if it was not significant, and that he could have taken some measures to prevent him from committing the ADRV.https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44115062 ====2016 Summer Olympics ad hoc court==== The ad hoc court for the 2016 Olympics had registered 18 cases by 3 August, surpassing the record two days before the Opening Ceremony. 11 of the cases were related to the various bans on Russian athletes related to the [[Doping in Russia#July 2016|allegations of state-sponsored doping]] documented in the [[McLaren Report|McLaren report]].Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Media_Release__English__030816_final.pdf Media Release: 18 cases registered – Status as of 3 August 2016] Accessed 3 August 2016 By the end of the Games the total number of cases was 28, 16 of which were related to the eligibility of Russian athletes. *On 3 August the ad hoc court dismissed the appeal of the [[Russian Weightlifting Federation]] against its complete suspension under article 12.4 of the [[International Weightlifting Federation]] (IWF) anti-doping rules. The panel stated that the findings of the McLaren report constituted "conduct connected with or associated with doping", and found that the IWF had acted within its discretion when it decided that the RWF had brought the sport of weightlifting into disrepute. The panel noted that the re-analysis of doping tests from the [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008]] and [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012 Olympics]] had found nine cases of Russian athletes testing positive for [[Turinabol]] and stated that this indicated a centralized doping programme. Furthermore, the panel commented that the positive tests for Turinabol were consistent with the evidence provided by Dr [[Grigory Rodchenkov]] for the report.Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/REASONED_AWARD_OG_16-09.pdf CAS OG 16/09] Accessed 5 August 2016 *A separate panel of the ad hoc court found that the [[International Rowing Federation]] (FISA) had correctly applied the eligibility criteria outlined in the IOC decision of 24 July when it denied the entry of 17 athletes. One of the criteria in the IOC decision was that the ROC could not enter athletes that had previously served a doping ban. The CAS panel deciding the case involving the rowers [[Anastasia Karabelshikova]] and [[Ivan Podshivalov]] found this criterion unenforceable, and ordered FISA to evaluate the athletes according to the remaining criteria.Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Media_Release__English__Karabelshikova_final.pdf Rowing: The Appeal of Anastasia Karabelshikova and Ivan Podshivalov is partially upheld by CAS] Accessed 4 August 2016 The panel referred to previous decisions on the "Osaka rule" and the BOA by-law. The panel compared the IOC decision with the IAAF decision on Russian athletes, and noted that the IOC, unlike the IAAF, had left athletes with a previous doping conviction without any path to participation, contravening principles of [[natural justice]].Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/final_award_CAS_OG_16-13.pdf CAS OG 16/13] Accessed 4 August 2016 The same conclusion was shortly thereafter reached in the case of swimmer [[Yulia Efimova]],Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/FINAL_AWARD_OG_16-04.pdf CAS OG 16/04] Accessed 9 August 2016 who subsequently competed and medalled at the Games.{{cite news|title=Rio Olympics 2016: Russia's Yulia Efimova beaten to gold by Lilly King of USA|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/36686211|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 June 2016}} *In the cases of canoeists [[Natalia Podolskaya (canoeist)|Natalia Podolskaya]] and [[Alexander Dyachenko]] and rower [[Ivan Balandin]] the panels dismissed the applications, upholding the part of the IOC decision of 24 July that removed the presumption of innocence from Russian athletes. Balandin challenged the legality of the IOC decision, while Podolskaya and Dyachenko only challenged its application. The panel in Balandin's case found no reason to annul the second paragraph of the IOC decision which, among other criteria, established that nobody implicated in the McLaren report was eligible for participation at the Games. The panel noted that while the decision establishes a presumption of guilt, this presumption is rebuttable by individual athletes. All three athletes were found to have benefitted from the "Disappearing Positive Methodology" described in the McLaren report and thus failed to meet the eligibility criteria of the IOC decision. The panels differed as to which [[standard of proof]] they required for the athletes' rebuttal of this presumption.Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Award__FINAL_.pdf CAS OG 16/12] Accessed 9 August 2016Court of Arbitration for Sport: [http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/AWARD_16-19.pdf CAS OG 16/19] Accessed 9 August 2016 ===Other cases=== * In July 2015, in a case involving the issue of [[sex verification in sports]], the CAS issued an interim arbitral award suspending the regulations used by the IAAF to determine whether athletes with [[hyperandrogenism]] were eligible to compete in professional [[women's athletics]]. The regulations stated that athletes with testosterone levels above 10 nmol/L were not allowed to compete in the female category. The regulations were challenged by Indian sprinter [[Dutee Chand]]. The panel ordered the IAAF to file scientific evidence regarding the connection between athletic performance and elevated [[testosterone]] levels within two years of the issuance of the interim award.{{cite web|author=Court of Arbitration for Sport|title=CAS suspends IAAF Hyperandrogenism Regulations|url=http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Media_Release_3759_FINAL.pdf|accessdate=15 August 2016}}{{cite web|author=Court of Arbitration for Sport|title=Chand v. IAAF - Interim award|url=http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/award_internet.pdf|accessdate=15 August 2016}}{{cite news|title=Dutee Chand, Female Sprinter With High Testosterone Level, Wins Right to Compete|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/28/sports/international/dutee-chand-female-sprinter-with-high-male-hormone-level-wins-right-to-compete.html?_r=1|work=The New York Times|accessdate=15 August 2016}} This deadline was extended by two months by the CAS after an agreement between the parties.{{cite news|title=Dutee Chand to run in World Championships, gets favourable order from CAS|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/more-sports/athletics/dutee-chand-to-run-in-world-championships-gets-favourable-order-from-cas/articleshow/59824283.cms|work=The Times of India|accessdate=29 July 2017}} In January 2018 the CAS suspended the case for six months, asking the IAAF to clarify whether it intended to replace the disputed regulations with new rules which would not affect Chand's events. If the IAAF were to modify its rules the case would terminate. The original regulations remain suspended.{{cite web|author=Court of Arbitration for Sport|title=The application of the IAAF hyperandrogenism regulations remain suspended|url=http://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Media_Release_3759_Jan_2018.pdf|accessdate=20 January 2018}}{{cite news|last=Singh |first=Navneet |title=Advantage Dutee Chand as CAS suspends world athletics body’s gender policy|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/other-sports/advantage-dutee-chand-as-cas-suspends-world-athletics-body-s-gender-policy/story-ygsRmsOtEpvmCasjjgTuHJ.html|work=Hindustan Times|accessdate=20 January 2018}} * The court ruled in 2006 that [[Gibraltar Football Association|Gibraltar]] had valid grounds for its application to join [[UEFA]], forcing the organisation to hand it provisional membership. At the next UEFA Congress, however, Gibraltar was overwhelmingly rejected in a vote, due to lobbying from Spain, in defiance of the CAS ruling.{{cite news|title=Gibraltar have failed in their attempt to become a member of Uefa.|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/6302889.stm|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=25 June 2012}} Gibraltar subsequently became a member of UEFA in 2013. In May 2016 CAS partially upheld Gibraltar's appeal against a decision by [[FIFA]] denying membership. The court did not grant FIFA membership, but ruled that FIFA should grant a full membership as soon as possible.{{cite news|title=CAS tells Fifa to reconsider Gibraltar’s membership ‘without delay’|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/02/cas-fifa-gibraltar-membership|work=The Guardian|accessdate=17 June 2016}} Gibraltar was granted membership at the FIFA congress held later the same month.{{cite news|title=Fifa: Kosovo and Gibraltar become members of world governing body|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36290169|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 June 2016}} * In 2010, the [[Irish Football Association | Irish Football Association (IFA)]] (the association of [[Northern Ireland]]) took its case to CAS after FIFA failed to prevent the [[Football Association of Ireland | Football Association of Ireland (FAI)]] (the association of the [[Republic of Ireland]]) from selecting Northern Irish-born players who had no blood link to the Republic.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/irish/8538702.stm IFA take case to CAS] The CAS ruled in favour of the FAI and FIFA by confirming that they were correctly applying the regulations.{{cite web|author=CAS/2010/A/2071|title=Irish Football Association v/ Football Association of Ireland, Daniel Kearns and FIFA|url=http://jurisprudence.tas-cas.org/Shared%20Documents/2071.pdf}} == Notes and references == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Court of Arbitration for Sport}} * {{Official website|http://www.tas-cas.org/}} ** [http://www.tas-cas.org/en/general-information/news-detail/article/list-of-hearings-9.html Current hearing schedule] * [http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2004/07/where_do_athletes_go_to_court.html "Where do athletes go to court?" ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', 1 July 2004] {{Portal bar|Olympics|Sports|Law|Switzerland}} [[Category:International arbitration courts and tribunals]] [[Category:Olympic organizations]] [[Category:Sports law]] [[Category:International sports bodies based in Switzerland]] [[Category:Organisations based in Lausanne]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1984]]

page.title: Dante Benedetti Diamond at Max Ulrich Field

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = Dante Benedetti Diamond at Max Ulrich Field | nickname = Benedetti Diamond | image = | fullname = | former_names = Max Ulrich Field (1953-1980) | location = Golden Gate Avenue and Masonic Avenue, [[San Francisco, CA]], [[United States|USA]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.776684|-122.448017|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1953 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of San Francisco]] | operator = University of San Francisco | surface = Natural grass | scoreboard = Electronic | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | capacity = 2,000 | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = 315 feet ([[Left field]])
415 feet ([[Baseball field#outfield|Center field]])
321 feet ([[Right field]]) | acreage = | tenants = [[San Francisco Dons baseball]] ([[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|D1]] [[West Coast Conference|WCC]]) (1953-present) }} '''Dante Benedetti Diamond at Max Ulrich Field''' is a [[baseball]] venue in [[San Francisco, California]], [[United States]]. It is home to the [[San Francisco Dons baseball]] team of the [[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[West Coast Conference]].{{cite web|title=Athletic Facilities |url=http://www.usfdons.com/information/facilities/index |work=USF Dons |accessdate=27 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60UqG3Onc?url=http://www.usfdons.com/information/facilities/index |archivedate=2011-07-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Built in 1953,{{cite web|title=Benedetti Diamond |url=http://usfblogtastic.blogspot.com/2007/03/benedetti-diamond.html |accessdate=27 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60UqL0yS5?url=http://usfblogtastic.blogspot.com/2007/03/benedetti-diamond.html |archivedate=2011-07-27 |date=March 21, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} the facility has a capacity of 2,000 spectators.{{cite web|last=The Editors of Baseball America|title=Baseball America 2007 Directory: Your Definitive Guide to the Game|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EXno1qQKoyIC&pg=PA304&lpg=PA304&dq=benedetti+diamond+capacity&source=bl&ots=8W78VUOasY&sig=n10QWKiIYMWXzirdPd4mdcBcjxo&hl=en&ei=lFswTqTrNYPQgAeAkLl-&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=benedetti%20diamond%20capacity&f=false|work=Google Books|accessdate=27 July 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422145903/https://books.google.com/books?id=EXno1qQKoyIC&pg=PA304&lpg=PA304&dq=benedetti+diamond+capacity&source=bl&ots=8W78VUOasY&sig=n10QWKiIYMWXzirdPd4mdcBcjxo&hl=en&ei=lFswTqTrNYPQgAeAkLl-&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=benedetti%20diamond%20capacity&f=false|dead-url=no|archivedate=2016-04-22}} The venue was originally called simply '''Max Ulrich Field'''. After its 1953 construction, it was named after Max Ulrich, a San Francisco resident who donated in his will [[USD|$]]358,000 to the university. The field took on its current name in 1980. In that year, Dons baseball coach [[Dante Benedetti]] retired after 29 years in charge of the program.{{cite web|last=Perkins |first=Andrea |title=The Life and Times of Dante Benedetti: Baseball, Business, and a Babe Named Chubs |url=http://www.coastnews.com/sf/dante/dante.htm |work=Coast News |accessdate=27 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60Uqy6GYD?url=http://www.coastnews.com/sf/dante/dante.htm |archivedate=2011-07-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The diamond was dedicated to him that same year. Until [[Nino Giarratano]] surpassed him in 2012, Benedetti was the program's all-time winningest coach, with 373 wins.{{cite web|last=Sorenson |first=Eric |title=One of My Simple Pleasures in Life |url=http://blogs.eastonbaseball.com/collegebaseballtoday/2012/03/03/one-of-my-simple-pleasures-in-life/ |work=College Baseball Today |accessdate=4 March 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65uquexUg?url=http://blogs.eastonbaseball.com/collegebaseballtoday/2012/03/03/one-of-my-simple-pleasures-in-life/ |archivedate=2012-03-04 |date=3 March 2012 |quote=San Francisco’s Nino Giarratano picked up his 374th win in his Dons coaching career with today’s 6-5, 10-inning win over Cal State Northridge. With the win he surpasses the legendary Dante Benedetti for the most wins in program history. |deadurl=yes |df= }} The playing field is surrounded by mesh netting, designed to protect spectators from [[foul ball]]s.{{cite web|last=Sorenson |first=Eric |title=The Campaign to Stop Bay Area Bullying |url=http://blogs.eastonbaseball.com/collegebaseballtoday/2012/02/24/the-campaign-to-stop-bay-area-bullying/ |work=College Baseball Today |accessdate=26 February 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65kNV9ICr?url=http://blogs.eastonbaseball.com/collegebaseballtoday/2012/02/24/the-campaign-to-stop-bay-area-bullying/ |archivedate=2012-02-26 |date=24 February 2012 |quote=Benedetti Diamond, which is crunched into a corner of the campus and is surrounded by netting (think the Henry Doorley Zoo bird aviary). |deadurl=yes |df= }} Benedetti Diamond was upgraded in 2016 and includes Greenplay organic infill for safety, performance and low temperatures. == See also == * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] == References == {{West Coast Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{California NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in California]] [[Category:San Francisco Dons baseball]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1953]] [[Category:1953 establishments in California]]

page.title: Dort Federal Credit Union Event Center

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = Dort Federal Credit Union Event Center | image = File:Dort Federal Credit Union Event Center - Interior.JPG | former names = IMA Sports Arena
Perani Arena and Event Center | location = 3501 Lapeer Road
[[Flint, Michigan]] 48503 | broke_ground = 1967 | opened = October 1969 | owner = IMS Hockey Corp. | operator = IMS Hockey Corp. | surface = Multi-surface | cost = $10 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|10000000|1969}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = | capacity = [[Concert]]s: 6,469
[[Ice hockey]]: 4,021
[[Boxing]]: 5,109
[[Standing room only]]: 400 | tenants = [[Flint Generals]] ([[International Hockey League (1945–2001)|IHL]]) (1969–1985)
[[Flint Spirits]] (IHL) (1985–1990)
[[Flint Bulldogs]] ([[CoHL]]) (1991–1993)
[[Flint Generals]] ([[United Hockey League|UHL]]/[[International Hockey League (2007–2010)|IHL]]) (1993–2010)
[[Flint Flames]] ([[Indoor Football League (1999–2000)|IFL]]) (2000)
[[Flint Fuze]] ([[Continental Basketball Association|CBA]]) (2000–2001)
[[Michigan Pirates]] ([[Continental Indoor Football League|CIFL]]) (2007)
[[Flint Phantoms]] (CIFL) (2008)
[[Michigan Warriors]] ([[North American Hockey League|NAHL]]) (2010–2015)
[[Flint Firebirds]] ([[Ontario Hockey League|OHL]]) (2015–present)
[[Waza Flo]] ([[Major Arena Soccer League|MASL]]) (2015–present) }} '''Dort Federal Credit Union Event Center''' (originally '''IMA Sports Arena''' and formerly '''Perani Arena and Event Center''') is a sports, entertainment and convention venue located in [[Flint, Michigan]]. It opened in 1969. ==Facilities== [[File:Dort Federal Credit Union Event Center - Exterior.JPG|thumbnail|Exterior]] The main [[arena]] of the complex, the largest exhibit hall of complex, features {{convert|29280|ft2|m2}} of space and can accommodate 4,021 for [[ice hockey]] and 6,069 for [[concerts]], plus 400 in standing room. The second arena in the complex features {{convert|27206|ft2|m2}} of space. Both arenas are frequently used for trade shows, hockey games and other sports. In addition, the main arena is used for concerts. Initially named the IMA an acronym for the Industrial Mutual Association. Being the second such complex in Flint, MI. named the IMA. The original IMA was torn down and replaced at this new location. The complex was named for [[Bob Perani]], owner of [[Perani's Hockey World]], a sports equipment retailer in Flint. Perani's Hockey World paid for naming rights to the complex. Bob Perani was a goalie for the [[Flint Generals]] from 1969 to 1974. His jersey #1 is one of only 5 numbers retired by the team. ==Tenants== ===Current=== On January 13, 2015, the [[Plymouth Whalers]] of the [[Ontario Hockey League]] announced they would be relocated to Flint and will play at Perani Arena, with OHL approval. That team is now known as the [[Flint Firebirds]]. In September 2015, the [[Detroit Waza]] of the [[Major Arena Soccer League]] announced their relocation to Flint. The team will operate as simply "[[Waza Flo]]" during the [[2015–16 Major Arena Soccer League season]]. Local high schools and colleges use the arena for their commencement ceremonies. Perani Arena is also usually the first stop for the [[Shrine Circus]] every year. The Perani Arena also holds the General RV Show every year. ===Former=== Previous tenants of the arena include the [[Flint Generals]] [[International Hockey League (1945-2001)|IHL]] hockey team from 1969 to 1985, the [[Flint Spirits]] hockey team from 1985 to 1990, the [[Flint Bulldogs]] hockey team from 1991 to 1993, the [[Flint Fuze]] [[basketball]] team from 2000 to 2001 and the Flint Flames [[indoor American football|indoor football]] team which only lasted the 2000 season. The most recent iteration of the Flint Generals moved into the arena in 1993 and departed in 2010. From 2010 through 2015, the arena was the home of the [[Michigan Warriors]] of the [[North American Hockey League]]. The [[Michigan Pirates]] of the [[Continental Indoor Football League]] (formerly based in [[Port Huron, Michigan|Port Huron]]) played their first and second-round playoff games at the Perani Arena, hoping Flint would be a potential relocation site. While the Pirates folded, Perani Arena was home to the CIFL expansion team [[Flint Phantoms]] for the 2008 season.[http://www.flintphantoms.com/ Flint Phantoms Professional Indoor Football] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite news |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |title=Report: Plymouth Whalers to announce move to Flint |url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/2015/01/13/plymouth-whalers-news-conference/21703871/ |date=January 13, 2015 |accessdate=January 14, 2015}} {{cite news |last=Bartkowiak |first=Dave |publisher=Click On Detroit |title=Plymouth Whalers to relocate to Flint |url=http://www.clickondetroit.com/sports/hockey/plymouth-whalers-move-to-flint-to-be-announced-wednesday-reports-say/30682314 |date=January 14, 2015 |accessdate=January 14, 2015}} {{cite news |first=Aaron |last=McMann |newspaper=[[The Flint Journal]] |via=[[MLive.com]] |title='Flint Firebirds' unveiled as name for Flint's new OHL team |url=http://www.mlive.com/sports/flint/index.ssf/2015/03/flint_firebirds_unveiled_as_na.html |date=March 16, 2015 |accessdate=March 16, 2015}} {{cite news |first=Eric |last=Woodyard |newspaper=[[The Flint Journal]] |publisher=[[Booth Newspapers]] |location=[[Flint, MI]] |title=Major Arena Soccer League team moves home games to Flint's Dort Federal Event Center |url=http://www.mlive.com/sports/flint/index.ssf/2015/09/major_arena_soccer_league_team.html |date=September 29, 2015 |accessdate=October 29, 2015}} }} ==External links== * revision.comment: /* See also */ remove redlinked see also
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} [[Image:RobinsonThrowing2.jpg|thumb|1907 photograph of early American football uniform with elbow pads worn by [[Bradbury Robinson]], who threw the first legal forward pass]] [[Image:Splav tactical elbow pads.jpg|thumb|Russian military style elbow pads]] '''Elbow pads''' are protective [[padding|padded]] gear worn on the [[Elbow-joint|elbow]]s to protect them against [[injury]] during a fall or a strike.
Elbow pads are worn by many athletes, especially [[Ice hockey|hockey players]], [[bicycling|cyclists]], [[roller skating|roller skaters]], [[skateboarding|skateboarders]], [[volleyball|volleyball players]], [[skiers]] and [[Professional wrestler|wrestlers]]. Wrestlers sometimes use elbow pads as weapons by slapping their opponents, or take it off for an '''Atomic Elbow.'''
[[Soldiers]] also often wear elbow pads.
==See also== *[[Knee pads]] *[[Shoulder pads]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Elbow Pad}} [[Category:Safety clothing]] [[Category:Protective gear]] [[Category:Armwear]] [[Category:Ice hockey equipment]] [[Category:Bandy equipment]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Disabled sports organisations to [[:Category:Disabled sports organizations]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
[[Image:FIPFA Emblem 08 small.png |thumb|right|FIPFA logo]]
'''FIPFA''', the '''Fédération Internationale de Powerchair Football Association''', is the international governing body of [[powerchair football]]. It is headquartered in [[Paris]] in [[France]].
In 2006, representatives of 9 nations met in [[Coimbra]] in [[Portugal]] and then in [[Atlanta]] in the [[United States]] to develop a standardized set of laws for the game and to form and international governing body.
==Organization== FIPFA is governed by an Executive Council with 10 members, each elected for 4 years. The President supervises the proposals put forth by commissions that work together for the development of the discipline throughout the world.
FIPFA is organized similar to [[FIFA]], with several international zones. Currently, the only organized zone is the European Powerchair Football Association ([[EPFA]]), although the Powerchair Football Conference of the Americas (PFCA) is currently in the process of being organized. Eventually, the goal is to have zones for Asia and Africa as well. ==Rules== The rules of the game are fairly simple like regular football (soccer.) The object of the game is to kick (using a specially designed wheelchair) the ball into the goal. There are three players on the field at the same time plus a goalie.
==Events== {{main|World Powerchair Football Championships}}
==World Cup== There are competitions every four years. The first World Cup competition was hosted in Japan in 2007, and was won by the US National Team. The US team successfully defended its title in Paris in 2011. The most recent FIPFA World Cup was hosted in the USA in July 2017 and was won by France.
==External links== *[http://www.fipfa.org Official website]
[[Category:International sports organizations]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 2006]] [[Category:2006 establishments in France]] [[Category:Disabled sports organizations]] [[Category:Wheelchair sports]] [[Category:Association football governing bodies]] [[Category:International organizations based in France]]

''' Felicia Stoler, D.C.N.''' is an [[United States|American]] registered [[dietitian]] and [[exercise physiologist]] who has hosted ''[[Honey, We're Killing the Kids]]'', a television series originally developed by the [[BBC]] that shows parents the consequences of poor parenting, using [[Computer-generated imagery|computer-generated images]] of what their children may look like as adults if they continue with their present life-style, [[diet (nutrition)|dietary]] and exercise habits. Stoler has hosted the American edition, which appears as a one-hour weekly series on [[TLC (TV channel)|The Learning Channel]] in the United States and the [[Food Network (Canada)|Food Network]] in [[Canada]].<ref>Garrison, Kimberly. [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DN&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI|DN&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=11C12CCD5F7329A8&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM " Felicia Stoler wants you to stop killing your kids, Dietitian and TLC show host wants you to set a good example, eat right, exercise... and turn off that TV"], ''[[Philadelphia Daily News]]'', October 4, 2007. Accessed November 15, 2008.</ref><ref name=TLC>[http://tlc.discovery.com/guides/family/health-101/honey/bio/felicia.html Meet the Host of Honey We're Killing the Kids!], [[TLC (TV channel)]]. Accessed November 15, 2008.</ref>
Stoler attended [[Tulane University]], where she graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in political science and sociology. She attended [[Columbia University]], where she majored in applied physiology and nutrition and was awarded a [[Master of Science]] degree. In 2008, she completed a doctorate in clinical nutrition (D.C.N.) at the [[University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey]].<ref name=TLC/>
Stoler grew up in [[Marlboro Township, New Jersey]], where she attended Marlboro Middle School and [[Marlboro High School]]. {{Asof|2007}}, she lived with her children in nearby [[Holmdel Township, New Jersey]].<ref>Tesoriero, Tobi Drucker. [http://livinginmedia.com/article/felicia_stoler_spreading_health_with_a_little_tlc.html 'Felicia Stoler: Spreading Health With A Little TLC"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122003919/http://www.livinginmedia.com/article/felicia_stoler_spreading_health_with_a_little_tlc.html |date=2008-11-22 }}, ''living Marlboro'', July 1, 2007. Accessed November 15, 2008. "Stoler calls both Holmdel and Marlboro home. She grew up in Marlboro, where she attended the Delfino (Central School), Marlboro Middle School, and Marlboro High School (her family still owns a home in town). Now she, along with her 9-year-old daughter Isabella and 6-year- old son Zachary, live in Holmdel."</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

Lindquist | captain = {{flagicon|HUN}} Vladimir Dubek | honors = | affiliates = | website = https://web.archive.org/web/20090220142529/http://fradihoki.hu/ }} {{Ferencvárosi TC sections}} '''Ferencvárosi Torna Club Jégkorong Szakosztály''' is a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] [[ice hockey]] team that currently plays in the [[OB I bajnokság]] and in the [[MOL Liga]]. They play their home games at Pesterzsébeti Jégcsarnok, located in [[Budapest]]. In 1950–1951 the club was named ''ÉDOSZ Budapest'' and from 1951 to 1957 it was named ''Budapesti Kinizsi''. The team is part of the ''Ferencvárosi Torna Club'' sports organization. == Achievements == *'''[[OB I bajnokság]]:''' **'''Winners (25)''' : 1951, 1955, 1956, 1961, 1962, 1964, 1967, 1971, 1972, 1973, 1974, 1975, 1976, 1977, 1978, 1979, 1980, 1984, 1989, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1997 *'''Hungarian Cup (Ice Hockey):''' **'''Winners (13)''' : 1968, 1969, 1973, 1974, 1975, 1976, 1977, 1979, {{merge|The Official Album of the 2002 FIFA World Cup|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox album | name = Fever Pitch | type = soundtrack | artist = Various artists | cover = | alt = | released = 2002 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = | label = [[Sony Music Entertainment]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} '''''Fever Pitch''''' was the official soundtrack to the [[The Official Album of the 2002 FIFA World Cup|2002 FIFA World Cup]], held in Japan and South Korea. The album featured popular artists from several of the countries represented at the World Cup including [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Nelly Furtado]] and [[Bomfunk MC's]]. The album was released by [[Sony Music Entertainment]]. ==Track listing== {{Track listing | extra_column = Artist(s) | total_length = | title1 = [[Boom (Anastacia song)|Boom]] | note1 = Official World Cup song | writer1 = Anastacia, [[Glen Ballard]] | extra1 = [[Anastacia]] | length1 = 3:18 | title2 = Live For Love United | note2 = [[France]]; World | writer2 = | extra2 = [[Peabo Bryson]] | length2 = | title3 = (Crack It) Something Going On | note3 = [[Finland]] | writer3 = | extra3 = [[Bomfunk MC's]], ft. [[Jessica Folcker]] | length3 = | title4 = [[Let's Get Loud]] | note4 = [[United States]] | writer4 = [[Gloria Estefan]], [[Kike Santander]] | extra4 = [[Jennifer Lopez]] | length4 = | title5 = Sunrise | note5 = [[Denmark]] | writer5 = | extra5 = [[Safri Duo]] Meets [[Ayla (producer)|Ayla]] | length5 = | title6 = World At Your Feet | note6 = [[Belgium]] | writer6 = | extra6 = [[Lara Fabian]] | length6 = | title7 = Let It Out | note7 = [[England]] | writer7 = | music7 = | extra7 = [[A1 (band)|a1]] | length7 = | title8 = Party | note8 = [[Portugal]] | writer8 = | extra8 = [[Nelly Furtado]] | length8 = | title9 = True East Side | note9 = [[South Korea]] | writer9 = | extra9 = [[g.o.d]], ft. Park]] | length9 = 3:56 | title10 = We Will Be Heroes | note10 = [[Germany]] | writer10 = | extra10 = [[Die Toten Hosen]] | length10 = | title11 = [[Anthem (The 2002 FIFA World Cup Official Anthem)|Anthem]] | note11 = World | writer11 = Vangelis | extra11 = [[Vangelis]] | length11 = | title12 = Fever | note12 = [[Italy]] | writer12 = | extra12 = [[Elisa (Italian singer)|Elisa]] | length12 = | title13 = Bringing the World Back Home | note13 = [[Mexico]] | writer13 = | extra13 = [[OV7]] | length13 = | title14 = BLZ | note14 = [[Japan]] | writer14 = | extra14 = [[Mondo Grosso]] | length14 = | title15 = Shake the House | note15 = [[Spain]] | writer15 = | extra15 = [[Mónica Naranjo]] | length15 = | title16 = Vittoria | note16 = [[England]] | writer16 = | extra16 = [[Opera Babes]] | length16 = | title17 = Brave, Strong & True | note17 = [[South Africa]] | writer17 = | extra17 = [[Bongo Maffin]] | length17 = | title18 = World of Make Believe | note18 = [[United States]]; Latin America | writer18 = | extra18 = [[Chayanne]] | length18 = | title19 = Gol | note19 = [[Brazil]] | writer19 = | extra19 = Communion, ft. [[Idaho Horsemen]] {{small|([[American West Football Conference|AWFC]]) (2019-future)}} | embedded = | website = {{URL|http://www.fordidahocenter.com/|Venue Website}} | publictransit = }} The '''Ford Idaho Center''' is a complex of sports and entertainment venues in [[Nampa, Idaho|Nampa]], [[Idaho]], approximately {{convert|15|mi|km}} west of [[Boise, Idaho|Boise]]. ==About== The Ford Idaho Center Arena is best known for [[rodeo]]. It annually hosts the [[Snake River Stampede Rodeo|Snake River Stampede]], considered one of the nation's top rodeos, during the third week in July. The Stampede moved indoors to the Ford Arena in 1997; it was formerly held in an outdoor stadium (now demolished) near Lakeview Park.[http://www.snakeriverstampede.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=126&Itemid=208 Snake River Stampede.com] - history - accessed 2011-10-27 Since 1999, the [[Professional Bull Riders]] (PBR) has hosted a [[Built Ford Tough Series]] (originally Bud Light Cup) event at the Ford Idaho Center in what has been a major stop of the tour. Ford Arena is used for concerts, trade shows, sporting events, and other events. It is the former home of the [[Idaho Stampede]], then of the [[Continental Basketball Association]] from 1997-2005 and the [[Idaho Stallions]] of the now defunct [[Indoor Professional Football League]] in their inaugural season of 1999. Ford Arena is the former home of the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] Division II Men's Basketball Tournament. Upon its completion, the tournament moved to the Ford Idaho Center in 1998 from its former home on the campus of [[Northwest Nazarene University]]. The tournament moved in 2000 when NNU left the NAIA to join the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] in [[NCAA Division II|Division II]]. In March 2004, the Ford Idaho Center Arena was the home court for the [[Boise State Broncos|Boise State]] [[Boise State Broncos men's basketball|men's basketball team]] for a second round matchup in the [[National Invitation Tournament|NIT]] against the [[University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee|UWM Panthers]]. The game was moved to the Ford Idaho Center due to a prior scheduled [[Metallica]] concert at Boise State's [[Taco Bell Arena]]. The game drew a crowd of 10,153, the largest for a basketball game in the arena's history. BSU and [[Idaho Vandals men's basketball|Idaho]] played a non-conference basketball game at the arena on December 31, 2011; the Broncos won 76-73 before 7,540 spectators.[http://www.espnnorthwest.com/article/2011/dec/31/turnovers-cost-vandals-loss-boise/ ESPN Northwest] - Turnovers cost Vandals in loss to Boise - 2011-12-31 The Ford Amphitheater has played host to music festivals, including the [[Vans Warped Tour]], the [[Gigantour]], [[Lilith Fair]], and the [[Mayhem Festival]]. [[Pearl Jam]] performed during their [[Binaural Tour]] on November 3, 2000, with [[Supergrass]] as their opening act. The show was filmed and later released as a live album, titled ''[[11/3/00 – Boise, Idaho]]''. [[The Rolling Stones]] played their first concert in the state of Idaho at the arena during their [[A Bigger Bang Tour]] on Tuesday, November 14, 2006.[http://www.iorr.org/tour05/boise.htm io0rr.org/tour05/boise] - accessed 2011-10-27 The Ford Idaho Center has been the Treasure Valley stop for the [[Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus]], [[Disney on Ice]] and [[Champions on Ice]] since it opened. On January 14, 2014, the City of Nampa announced [[Ford]] as the new title sponsor for the Idaho Center. As part of the deal, Ford will pay the City of Nampa $1 million over five years.[http://www.ktvb.com/news/Ford-to-become-title-sponsore-for-Idaho-Center-240154321.html Ford to become title sponsor for Idaho Center] - accessed 2014-01-14 In 2017, it was announced that the [[Idaho Horsemen]] indoor football team would begin play in 2019. ==Venues== *Ford Arena {{small|(formerly the "Idaho Center Arena")}} *Ford Amphitheater {{small|(formerly the "Idaho Center Amphitheater)}} *Ford Sports Park *Ford Idaho Horse Park {{small|(formerly the "Idaho Center Horse Park")}} Venues include an indoor [[arena]] opened in 1997 with a [[seating capacity]] of 12,279 and {{convert|31200|sqft|m2}} of floor space and a 10,500-seat outdoor [[amphitheater]] opened in 1998 with a 60-by-40-foot stage. Additionally, the Ford Idaho Horse Park is used for horse shows and the Ford Sports Center is utilized for indoor track and field events, including the home meets of the [[Boise State University]] [[Boise State Broncos|Broncos]] track teams. It features a 200-meter indoor track and hosted the 2012 NCAA Indoor Track Championships. ==See also== * [[List of contemporary amphitheatres]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.fordidahocenter.com/ Ford Idaho Center website] *[http://www.concerthotels.com/venue-reviews/idaho-center-reviews/302515 Idaho Center Visitors Reviews] {{coord|43.608106|-116.508175|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Idaho]] [[Category:Sports in Boise, Idaho]] [[Category:Convention centers in Idaho]] [[Category:Amphitheaters in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Idaho]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Canyon County, Idaho]] [[Category:Nampa, Idaho]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Canyon County, Idaho]] [[Category:Continental Basketball Association venues]] [[Category:1997 establishments in Idaho]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1997]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Idaho]] [[Category:Arena football venues]]

'''West Newbury, Massachusetts''' |trainer=[[Christopher Daniels]]
[[Dave Finlay]]
[[Ohio Valley Wrestling|OVW]]{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} |debut=November 5, 1999{{cite web|url=http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=691|title=John Cena " Wrestlers Database " CAGEMATCH – The Internet Wrestling Database|publisher=Cagematch|accessdate=August 3, 2014}} }} }} '''John Felix Anthony Cena Jr.''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|iː|n|ə}}; born April 23, 1977) is an American professional wrestler, actor, rapper, and television host. He is currently signed to [[WWE]], where he appears for both the [[Raw (WWE brand)|Raw]] and [[SmackDown (WWE brand)|SmackDown]] [[WWE brand extension|brands]]. Cena gained fame in the WWE in the early 2000s, portraying a trash-talking rapper.{{cite web|last1=Truitt|first1=Brian|title='Flintstones' adds to John Cena's kid appeal|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2015/03/10/wwe-flintstones-john-cena-exclusive/24701947/|publisher=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=May 16, 2016}}{{cite web|title=WWE News: The story of John Cena's rap character creation recalled by a former WWE creative team member|url=http://www.prowrestling.net/artman/publish/WWE/article10016922.shtml|website=prowrestling.net|accessdate=May 16, 2016}} This success promoted Cena to act as the company's [[franchise player]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/11/02/top-50-wrestlers-of-all-time?page=4|title=Top 50 Wrestlers of All Time|publisher=IGN|accessdate=November 15, 2014}} and its public face,{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/editors-choice-who-will-be-the-next-john-cena|title=Who will be the next John Cena?|date=July 31, 2015|publisher=WWE|accessdate=October 12, 2015|quote=[...] only a handful of competitors can say they've been the face of WWE. John Cena has filled that role for 11 years now.}} which later prompted a transition to his current character, which he describes as a "[[wiktionary:goody two shoes|goody-two shoes]] [[Superman]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/sports/2016/04/john-cena-interview|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|title=A Candid Q&A With John Cena: WWE's Polarizing Company Man|first1=Thomas|last1=Golianopoulos|accessdate=May 16, 2016}} Under his current incarnation, Cena has attained mainstream fame, and has won 25 [[Professional wrestling championship|championships]] throughout his career, with 16 reigns as a [[Professional wrestling championship#World championships|world champion]].Both the WWE Championsip and the now defunct World Heavyweight Championship were considered world titles in WWE.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/johncena|title=John Cena|website=WWE.com|quote=He's a 16-time WWE World Champion}} His 16 world title wins are tied with [[Ric Flair]]'s, per WWE records.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/article/john-cena-performs-530-pound-squat-in-a-darth-vader-mask|title=John Cena performs 530-pound pause squat in a Darth Vader mask for Star Wars Day|date=May 4, 2018|first=Ryan|last=Murphy|website=WWE.com|quote=The 16-time World Champion}} Cena is a [[List of WWE United States Champions|five-time]] [[WWE United States Championship|United States Champion]] and a four-time [[World tag team championship|world tag team champion]]. He is also a [[Money in the Bank ladder match]] winner ([[Money in the Bank (2012)|2012]]), a two-time [[Royal Rumble]] winner ([[Royal Rumble (2008)|2008]], [[Royal Rumble (2013)|2013]]), and a three-time Superstar of the Year [[Slammy Award]] winner ([[Slammy Award#2009|2009]], [[Slammy Award#2010|2010]], [[Slammy Award#2012|2012]]). He has also headlined WWE's flagship event [[WrestleMania]] on five occasions ([[WrestleMania 22|2006]], [[WrestleMania 23|2007]], [[WrestleMania XXVII|2011]], [[WrestleMania XXVIII|2012]], and [[WrestleMania 29|2013]]) as well as many other [[List of WWE pay-per-view events|WWE pay-per-views]]. Despite his success, Cena's character is met with mixed critical reception, and he is considered one of the most polarizing professional wrestlers ever.{{cite web|last1=Ross|first1=Jim|authorlink1=Jim Ross|title=Cena's a polarizing figure because of WWE's failure to build around him|url=http://www.foxsports.com/other/story/john-cena-s-a-polarizing-figure-because-of-wwe-s-failure-to-build-around-him-081114|publisher=[[Fox Sports]]|accessdate=May 16, 2016}} Outside of wrestling, Cena released the album ''[[You Can't See Me]]'' (2005), which gained platinum certification in the United States. Cena has also enjoyed success as an actor, starring in ''[[The Marine]]'' (2006), ''[[12 Rounds (film)|12 Rounds]]'' (2009), ''[[Legendary (film)|Legendary]]'' (2010), ''[[The Reunion (2011 American film)|The Reunion]]'' (2011), ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'' (2015), ''[[The Wall (2017 film)|The Wall]]'' (2017), ''[[Ferdinand (film)|Ferdinand]]'' (2017), and ''[[Bumblebee: The Movie|Bumblebee]]'' (2018).{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/news/article_1239672.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522101526/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/news/article_1239672.php|deadurl=yes|archivedate=May 22, 2008|title=WWE Superstar John Cena bust onto DVD with The Marine|accessdate=June 12, 2008|date=January 4, 2007|last=Luce|first=Patrick|publisher=Monster & Critics|df=}} He has also made several guest appearances on television, and was the host of the reality show ''[[American Grit]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/american-grit/904180|title=American Grit|website=TVGuide.com|accessdate=November 8, 2016}} Cena is also known for his involvement in numerous philanthropic causes, namely the [[Make-A-Wish Foundation]], where he has granted more than 500 wishes, the most in Make-A-Wish history.[http://espn.go.com/espn/story/_/id/13480710/wwe-star-john-cena-grant-milestone-500th-make-wish-request Wish granted! WWE star John Cena to grant 500th Make-A-Wish request] [[ESPN]].com; August 23, 2015; by Associated Press. ==Early life== John Felix Anthony Cena Jr.{{cite web|url=https://www.today.com/popculture/john-cena-pops-question-nikki-bella-wrestlemania-33-she-said-t109923|title=John Cena pops the question to Nikki Bella at WrestleMania 33 — and she said yes!|first=Randee|last=Dawn|work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]|date=April 3, 2017|accessdate=April 8, 2018}} was born on April 23, 1977, in [[West Newbury, Massachusetts]]{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/Bios/cena.html|title=SLAM! Sports biography|accessdate=May 5, 2007|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer|CANOE]]|date=February 6, 2005}} to Carol (''née'' Lupien) and John Felix Anthony Cena.{{cite news|last=Albright|first=Bob|title=Heavyweight homecoming: WWE champion John Cena reflects on road to stardom|work=[[The Daily News of Newburyport]]|date=June 11, 2007|url=http://www.newburyportnews.com/sports/x845810493/Heavyweight-homecoming-WWE-champion-John-Cena-reflects-on-road-to-stardom|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sfdo792J?url=http://www.newburyportnews.com/sports/x845810493/Heavyweight-homecoming-WWE-champion-John-Cena-reflects-on-road-to-stardom|archivedate=September 11, 2010|accessdate=September 9, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=mdy}} He has an older brother (Stephen) and three younger brothers (Dan, Matt, and Sean).{{cite web|url=http://sports.ign.com/articles/607/607819p2.html|title=John Cena: The Champ is Here|accessdate=May 5, 2007|publisher=IGN}} His maternal grandfather was baseball player [[Tony Lupien]].{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/panorama_magazine/docs/2013-07_panorama_web/73|title=July 2013 Panorama Community Magazine by Panorama Community Magazine|publisher=ISSUU|accessdate=August 3, 2014}} He is of English, French-Canadian, and Italian ancestry.{{cite web|url=http://www.therichest.com/sports/wrestling/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-john-cena/?view=all|title=10 Things You Didn't Know About John Cena|work=TheRichest|quote=His father, John Cena Sr. is of Italian descent and his mother Carol Lupien, is of French Canadian and English descent.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226192835/http://www.therichest.com/sports/wrestling/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-john-cena/?view=all|archivedate=December 26, 2015|df=mdy-all}} Raised Catholic, he attended [[Central Catholic High School (Massachusetts)|Central Catholic High School]] in [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]] before transferring to [[Cushing Academy]], a private [[University-preparatory school|prep]] boarding school in [[Ashburnham, Massachusetts]]. He then attended [[Springfield College (Massachusetts)|Springfield College]] in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spfldcol.edu/homepage/athletics.nsf/2404afe7dd4d7ef545256bf4002a67e2/57db02504b5554ff45256c150026822c|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203090754/http://www.spfldcol.edu/homepage/athletics.nsf/2404afe7dd4d7ef545256bf4002a67e2/57db02504b5554ff45256c150026822c/|archivedate=February 3, 2014|title=1998 Football Roster|accessdate=May 5, 2007|publisher=Springfield College|deadurl=yes|df=mdy}} In college, he was a [[NCAA Division III]] [[All-America]]n [[Center (American football)|center]] on the [[college football]] team{{cite web|url=https://shopping.yahoo.com/p:John%20Cena:1927836016:page=biography|title=John Cena: biography|accessdate=May 11, 2007|publisher=Yahoo!|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070510001053/http://shopping.yahoo.com/p%3AJohn%20Cena%3A1927836016%3Apage%3Dbiography|archivedate=May 10, 2007|deadurl=yes}} and wore the number 54, which is still used on some of his WWE merchandise.{{cite web|url=http://shopzone.wwe.com/Product_detail.asp?cat=cat-johncena&productId=01-08596|title=John Cena Bulldog Basketball Jersey|accessdate=May 6, 2007|publisher=WWE|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080111024651/http://shopzone.wwe.com/Product_detail.asp?cat=cat-johncena&productId=01-08596|archivedate=January 11, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://shopzone.wwe.com/Product_detail.asp?cat=cat-johncena&productId=01-09163|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225163937/http://shopzone.wwe.com/Product_detail.asp?cat=cat-johncena&productId=01-09163|archivedate=December 25, 2007|title=John Cena Personalized Beware of Dog Football Jersey|accessdate=January 3, 2008|publisher=WWE}} Cena graduated from Springfield College in 1998 with a degree in [[exercise physiology]] and body movement,{{cite web|url=http://www.tribute.ca/people/John+Cena/17152|title=John Cena star bio|accessdate=May 5, 2007|publisher=Tribute.ca}} after which he pursued a career in bodybuilding{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FCO/is_5_2/ai_68951389?tag=artBody;col1|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224075721/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FCO/is_5_2/ai_68951389?tag=artBody;col1|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-02-24|title=Training Ground|first=Brad|last=Perkins|publisher=Wrestling Digest|accessdate=July 17, 2008|date=February 2001}} and worked as a limousine driver.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/news/archive/062606newmagazine|title=Inside WWE's New Magazine|accessdate=May 5, 2007|publisher=WWE|quote=Who would have guessed John Cena was once a limo driver}} == Professional wrestling career == === Ultimate Pro Wrestling (1999–2001) === Cena started training to become a professional wrestler in 1999 at [[Ultimate Pro Wrestling]]'s (UPW) California-based Ultimate University operated by [[Rick Bassman]]. Once he was placed into an in-ring role, Cena began using a semi-[[Cyborg|robotic]] character known as The Prototype.{{cite web|url=http://www.upw.com/features/cenahistory.htm|title=John Cena's WWE History|accessdate=July 4, 2007|publisher=UPW|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070730205606/http://www.upw.com/features/cenahistory.htm|archivedate=July 30, 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.upw.com/uu/alumni.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070401054209/http://www.upw.com/uu/alumni.htm|archivedate=April 1, 2007|title=Ultimate University/UPW alumni|accessdate=March 29, 2007|publisher=UPW}} Some of this period of his career was documented in the [[Discovery Channel]] program ''Inside Pro Wrestling School''.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} He held the UPW Heavyweight Championship for 27 days in April 2000. Cena wrestled for the UPW until March 2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=691&view=&page=4&gimmick=&year=&promotion=237®ion=&location=&arena=&showtype=&constellationType=&worker=|title=John Cena's Ultimate Pro Wrestling matches|accessdate=January 16, 2016|publisher=Cagematch}} === World Wrestling Federation/World Wrestling Entertainment/WWE === ==== Development and debut (2000–2002) ==== On October 10, 2000, while billed as The Prototype, Cena made his unofficial debut for the then [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF) on a ''[[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown]]'' taping in a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Dark match|dark match]] against Mikey Richardson, which he lost.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/00.htm|title=2000|publisher=Thehistoryofwwe.com|date=|accessdate=August 3, 2014}} He received another tryout on January 9, 2001, at a ''SmackDown'' taping in Oakland, California, this time defeating Aaron Aguilera. Cena wrestled again in a dark match at a ''SmackDown'' taping on March 13. In 2001, Cena signed a developmental contract with the WWF and was assigned to its [[Farm team#Professional wrestling|developmental territory]] [[Ohio Valley Wrestling]] (OVW).{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} During his time there, Cena wrestled under the [[ring name]] The Prototype and held the [[OVW Heavyweight Championship]] for three months and the [[OVW Southern Tag Team Championship]] (with [[Rico Constantino]]) for two months.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ky/ovw/ovw-h.html|title=OVW Heavyweight Title|accessdate=April 12, 2007|publisher=Wrestling-Titles}} Throughout 2001, Cena would receive four tryouts for the WWF main roster, as he wrestled multiple [[Jobber (professional wrestling)|enhancement talent]] wrestlers on both WWF [[house show]]s and in dark matches before WWF television events. Through the early months of 2002, Cena constantly found himself competing on house shows for the WWF, where he wrestled against the likes of [[Shelton Benjamin]] and [[Tommy Dreamer]]. After his main roster call up in June 2002, Cena would continue to appear on OVW programming until the September 25 taping of OVW, where he lost to Kenny Brolin in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Loser Leaves Town match|Loser Leaves OVW match]]. Cena would appear in a one-off appearance for the developmental farm in November under the ring name Mr. P in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Relevos Australianos|six-man tag team match]], where he teamed with future [[WWE Hall of Fame]]r [[Big Boss Man (wrestler)|Big Boss Man]] and [[Charlie Haas]] in a winning effort against [[Lance Cade]], [[Trevor Murdoch]] and [[Sean O'Haire]]. On the June 24 episode of ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'', [[Vince McMahon|Mr. McMahon]] ordered the entire roster to the ring and declared that he needed them to all find some ruthless aggression from within themselves and that he was looking for one of them to stand out from the rest of the pack.{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8DKkC4ud2Tk|time=13:35|title=Vince McMahon Introduces The Ruthless Aggression Era Featuring Rob Van Dam|publisher=jenniifer eure|work=YouTube}} Cena made his WWE television debut on the June 27, 2002, episode of ''SmackDown'' by answering an open challenge by [[Kurt Angle]].
