|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819182350/http://www.ugo.com/channels/sports/features/wrestling/?page=John%20Cena%20Interview%20&cur=John-Cena |archive-date=August 19, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Cena supports numerous American sports teams from his hometown area such as the [[Boston Bruins]], [[Boston Celtics]], [[Boston Red Sox]], and [[New England Patriots]], as well as English soccer team [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur FC]].{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/extramustard/02/04/john-cena-interview/ |title=John Cena talks Red Sox-Rays, future WWE stars and his top diva |last=Gray |first=Andy |date=February 4, 2009 |work=Sports Illustrated |accessdate=March 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427114703/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/extramustard/02/04/john-cena-interview/ |archivedate=April 27, 2009 }}{{cite web|last=Lawless|first=Josh|title=Premier League celebrity fans: Who do the likes of Usain Bolt and Barack Obama support?|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/premier-league-celebrity-fans-who-6016893|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=July 28, 2015|accessdate=February 11, 2017}} He has over 20 [[muscle car]]s, some of which are one-of-a-kind.{{cite video|date=2007|title=John Cena: My Life|medium=DVD|publisher=World Wrestling Entertainment}} Cena started learning [[Mandarin Chinese]] in 2016 to help WWE expand its reach, and he spoke in Mandarin at a press conference in China.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/qiwenqushi1/videos/917336468394379/|title=奇闻趣事 - Timeline {{!}} Facebook|website=www.facebook.com|access-date=August 10, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/sunrise/video/watch/39589782/exclusive-john-cena-stars-in-hilarious-new-comedy-blockers/|title=EXCLUSIVE: John Cena stars in hilarious new comedy 'Blockers'|website=Sunrise|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322143033/https://au.news.yahoo.com/sunrise/video/watch/39589782/exclusive-john-cena-stars-in-hilarious-new-comedy-blockers/|archive-date=March 22, 2018|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} He also revealed in April 2018 that he had learned to play the piano.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GnYGcx4EmN8|title=Everything John Cena Does in a Day - Vanity Fair|first=|last=Vanity Fair|date=April 5, 2018|publisher=|via=YouTube}} In December 2017, the [[Ford Motor Company]] filed a lawsuit against Cena for selling his 2017 [[Ford GT#Second generation (2016–present)|Ford GT]], therefore violating his purchase agreement. According to Ford, he signed a contract to keep the car for at least two years, but breached the agreement by selling it to make a net profit shortly after receiving it.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2017/12/02/ford-sues-actor-wwe-superstar-john-cena-over-his-car/915846001/ |title=John Cena sued by Ford for selling GT supercar |author=Woodyard, Chris |publisher=''[[USA Today]]'' |date=December 2, 2017 |accessdate=December 4, 2017}} In July 2018, Cena moved to China, where he settled in [[Yinchuan]]. He went on to create a YouTube show on WWE's channel, highlighting his trips to local stores and markets. He explained that he would be living there for a total of five months while he works on a short film with [[Jackie Chan]]. {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Keepmoat Stadium | image = [[File:Keepmoat Stadium Doncaster.jpg|250px]] | nickname = Black Bank, The Moat | fullname = Keepmoat Stadium | location = Stadium Way, Lakeside, [[Doncaster]], [[South Yorkshire]], [[England]] DN4 5JW | coordinates = {{coord|53|30|35|N|1|6|50|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | built = 2006 | opened = 3 August 2007 | owner = [[Doncaster Rovers Football Club]] | operator = [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers Football Club]] | seating_capacity = 15,231 | surface = [[Desso GrassMaster]] | tenants = [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] (2007–present)
[[Doncaster R.L.F.C.]] (2007–present)
[[Doncaster Rovers Belles L.F.C.|Doncaster Rovers Belles]] (2007–present)
[[Sheffield Eagles]] (2015)|
[[Doncaster Belles Juniors]] (2017-Present) | dimensions = | record attendance = [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] v [[Leeds United]] – 15,001 on 1 April 2008 |}} [[File:Keepmoat stadium doncaster layout.png|thumb|320px|Stadium seating area layout]] [[File:Keepmoat Stadium.jpg|thumb|250px|Keepmoat Stadium at night]] [[File:Keepmoat1.jpg|thumb|250px|Stadium during a match]] '''Keepmoat Stadium''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Doncaster]], [[England]], with a capacity of 15,231. It cost approximately [[Pound sterling|£]]20 million to construct, as part of the wider complex it resides within which in total cost approximately £32 million, and is used by [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]], [[Doncaster R.L.F.C.|Doncaster Rugby League Club]] and [[Doncaster Rovers Belles L.F.C.|Doncaster Rovers Belles Ladies Football Club]].{{cite web |url=http://www.smc-doncaster.co.uk/press/091106.html |title="Keepmoat Stadium" new name for centre-piece of £32million Lakeside Sports Complex |work=Stadium Management Company, Doncaster |date=20 November 2006 |accessdate=28 August 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008040303/http://www.smc-doncaster.co.uk/press/091106.html |archivedate= 8 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The first match at the stadium was a [[Rugby League]] match on 27 December 2006, when [[Sheffield Eagles]] beat [[Doncaster R.L.F.C.|Doncaster]] 16–10. The official opening of the Keepmoat Stadium was on 3 August 2007, with Doncaster Rovers playing a [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] XI in front of a crowd of 13,080. United won the game 2–0.{{cite web |url=http://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/rovers?articleid=3101104 |title=A taste of things to come |work=Doncaster Today |date=9 August 2007 |accessdate=28 August 2007}} On 19 June 2012, it was confirmed that Doncaster Rovers had secured a 99-year operating lease from Doncaster Metropolitan Borough Council to lead the management of the stadium with a view to improving operating results across the stadium sports partnership.{{cite web |url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/football/doncaster/rovers-welcome-keepmoat-lease-1-4659467 |title=Rovers welcome Keepmoat lease |work=Yorkshire Post |date=19 June 2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012}} At the Stadium Business Awards 2010, the stadium received the award for Best Matchday Experience. ==Facilities== The stadium itself is sponsored under a long-term contract by [[Keepmoat]], a company specialising in [[council housing]]. They have the rights to the naming of the stadium.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/doncaster/6170858.stm |title=Doncaster announce stadium name |work=[[BBC]] South Yorkshire |date=21 November 2006 |accessdate=17 April 2007}} ==Stands== ===East Stand=== The East Stand is sponsored by [[Bartercard|Bartercard UK]].[http://www.doncasterroversfc.co.uk/news/article/bartercard-uk-are-new-stand-sponsors-551645.aspx "DCLT", web] The area of the East Stand towards the South East corner is the Families area sponsored by Doncaster Culture and Leisure Trust and is known as the "DCLT" Families Stand.[http://www.dclt.co.uk/ "DCLT", web] ===West Stand=== This is the main match-day reception area with the stand sponsored by Estate.com. ===South Stand=== The South Stand, popularly known as the Black Bank, is sponsored by [[Polypipe]]. For Doncaster Rovers matches this is the stand that houses the Black Bank (the Ultras group of Doncaster Rovers supporters) and is decorated with flags and banners on match days, widely known for creating a fantastic atmosphere.http://blackbank.co.uk/about-the-black-bank/ ===North Stand=== The North Stand is sponsored by Corsan. The North Stand area closest to the East Stand is the usual location of visiting fans. Depending on the numbers of visitors, the availability of seats in this area are expanded westwards to meet demand. ===Capacity=== The all-seater stadium holds 15,231 spectators,{{cite web |url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/aroundthegrounds?articleid=2984467 |title=Doncaster Rovers – Keepmoat Stadium |work=Yorkshire Evening Post |date=27 June 2007 |accessdate=9 August 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928075401/http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/aroundthegrounds?articleid=2984467 |archivedate=28 September 2007}} 5,000 more than [[Belle Vue (football)|Belle Vue]], with improved legroom and disabled access.{{cite web |url=http://www.nads.org.uk/?page=89 |title=Doncaster Rovers |work=National Association of Disabled Supporters |date= |accessdate=28 August 2007}} Amongst the facilities in the new stadium is a new fans' bar, created to ensure fans have a place where they can enjoy pre-match drinks. The pitch itself incorporates a system of synthetic fibres interwoven with natural grass.{{cite web |url=http://www.architectureweek.org.uk/feature.asp?FeatureID=49 |title=Feature: Media Information Architecture Week Yorkshire |work=Architecture Week |date= |accessdate=28 August 2007}} This helps to maintain the pitch's integrity and prevents the playing surface from deteriorating throughout the course of the season. The pitch however does not have an under-soil heating system in-place, despite being a modern construction.{{cite web |url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/leedsunited/United-39left-in-the-dark39.3785953.jp |title=United 'left in the dark' by Rovers |work=Yorkshire Evening Post |date=16 February 2008 |accessdate=17 February 2008}} This has resulted in the postponement of a match within the first year of full operation. ==Adjoining sports complex facilities and stadia== A mini-stadium is situated beside the main stadium, featuring a six-lane running track and a 500-seat stand. The mini stadium is used by [[Doncaster Rovers Belles LFC|Doncaster Rovers Belles]], Doncaster Rovers Reserves, Doncaster Athletics Club, Doncaster RLFC's academy team, and the [[Doncaster Mustangs (American football)|Doncaster Mustangs]] [[American football]] team. ==Football== The first game played by Doncaster Rovers in the new stadium was on 1 January 2007 against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], whom they beat 3–0.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/southyorkshire/content/image_galleries/doncaster_rovers_keepmoat_john_ennis_gallery.shtml?3 |title=First day at Keepmoat |work=BBC South Yorkshire |date= |accessdate=28 August 2007}} The game also saw the first three red cards in the new stadium.{{cite web |url=http://www.htafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10312~32925,00.html |title=Doncaster vs Huddersfield |work=Huddersfield Town Official Website |date=1 January 2007 |accessdate=28 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214215342/http://www.htafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10312~32925%2C00.html |archivedate=14 February 2008 |df= }} Doncaster Rovers' [[centre forward]] [[Mark McCammon]] was the first player ever to score on the new pitch. Doncaster's first loss at the stadium came five days later at the hands of [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] when they defeated the Rovers 4–0 in the 3rd Round of the [[FA Cup 2006–07#Third round proper|FA Cup]].{{cite web |url=http://www.doncasterroversfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10329~36472,00.html |title=Doncaster Rovers Match Report – Doncaster Rovers 0 – Bolton Wanderers 4 |work=Doncaster Rovers Official Website |date=6 January 2007 |accessdate=10 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615110348/http://www.doncasterroversfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10329~36472%2C00.html |archivedate=15 June 2011 |df= }} On 14 January 2007, [[Doncaster Rovers Belles L.F.C.|Doncaster Rovers Belles]]' first match in the main stadium resulted in a 5–2 defeat to [[Leeds United L.F.C.|Leeds United]], before a crowd of 1,797.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/jan/15/womensfootball.sport|title=Belles ring changes at new home|author=Tony Leighton|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=15 November 2010|date=15 January 2007}} [[Vicky Exley]] was the first Belle to score on the new pitch.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/women/6261375.stm |title=Leeds deny Donny on stadium debut |work=BBC Sport |author=Tony Leighton |date=14 January 2007 |accessdate=2 August 2011}} The stadium hosted the final of the [[2012–13 FA Women's Cup]].{{cite news |date=26 May 2013 |title=FA Women's Cup final: Arsenal Ladies beat Bristol Academy |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22635611 |newspaper=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |accessdate=19 May 2014}} The highest ever attendance at the Keepmoat stadium was 15,001 for the visit of [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]].{{cite web |url=http://www.doncasterroversfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10329~38664,00.html |title=Doncaster Vs Leeds united |work=Doncaster Rovers Official Website |date=1 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615103318/http://www.doncasterroversfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10329~38664%2C00.html |archivedate=15 June 2011 |df= }} Rovers also achieved attendances of over 14,800 at the Keepmoat Stadium in games against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. On 3 March 2010, it hosted [[England national under-21 football team|England’s under-21s]] [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification Group 9]] match against [[Greece national under-21 football team|Greece’s under-21s]]. The hosts lost 2–1 with the visitors goals coming from [[Kyriakos Papadopoulos]] on the 28th minute and [[Yiannis Papadopoulos]] on the 49th minute while [[Nathan Delfouneso]] scored for the hosts on the 80th minute. ==Rugby League== The opening game played by [[Doncaster R.L.F.C.|Doncaster]] in the new stadium was against [[Sheffield Eagles]], to whom they lost 16–10 in front of 5,400 spectators. Sheffield Eagles (and former Dons') [[Richard Newlove]] was the first player to score try at the new stadium.{{cite web |url=http://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/doncaster-star-sport?articleid=1947571 |title=Eagles spoil Dons' opener at Keepmoat |work=Doncaster Today |date=28 December 2006 |accessdate=28 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929081130/http://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/doncaster-star-sport?articleid=1947571 |archivedate=29 September 2007 |df= }} On Sunday 27 July 2008, the stadium hosted a semi-final of the [[Challenge Cup|Rugby League Challenge Cup]] between [[Hull F.C.]] and [[Wakefield Trinity]]. Hull beat Trinity 32–24 in front of a crowd of 14,716. The stadium hosted the opening match of the [[2009 Rugby League Four Nations|2009 Gillette 4 Nations]] on Friday 23 October between co-hosts [[England national rugby league team|England]] and [[France national rugby league team|France]] attracting a crowd of 11,529. The stadium hosted the semi-final of the [[Challenge Cup|Rugby League Challenge Cup]] between [[Castleford Tigers|Castleford]] and [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] on Sunday 7 August 2011, Leeds winning 10-8 in front of 13,158 fans; another Challenge Cup Semi-Final between [[Hull F.C.|Hull FC]] and [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] took place at the stadium on 29 July 2016, Hull running out 16-12 winners. The Dons local rivals, Sheffield Eagles, used the stadium as their temporary home during the 2015 rugby league season. ==Other events== There have also been a variety of other events held in the Keepmoat Stadium, including two concerts in July 2007 featuring [[Ronan Keating]], [[Bryan Adams]] and [[McFly]]. In July 2008 there was also a show by [[Sir Elton John]] and his band. In September 2008, the stadium was used to host the BAFL (British American Football League) finals known as "Britbowl".http://www.bafl.org.uk/artman2/publish/BritBowl_46/index.asp In mid June 2009 opened its facilities to accommodate corporate events and private functions, the first of which being the marriage reception of Wesley and Claire Vaughan, June 2009. In November 2010, darts superstar [[Dennis Priestley]] held a darts exhibition at the Keepmoat Stadium. On 30 July 2011, Irish vocal pop band [[Westlife]] held a concert for [[Gravity Tour]] supporting their album [[Gravity (Westlife album)|Gravity]]. On 11 May 2013, an [[IBF]] Bantamweight World Title boxing match between [[Jamie McDonnell]] and [[Julio Ceja (boxer)|Julio Ceja]] took place at the Keepmoat Stadium, with McDonnell the winner. On 27 July 2013, an MMA even hosted by UCFC has held at the Keepmoat Stadium, the main event was between [[Ian Freeman]] and [[Ricco Rodriguez]] On 28 April 2016 it was announced that [[Rugby Union]] team [[Doncaster Knights]] would use the Keepmoat for a maximum of six games next season if they are to win promotion to the [[Aviva Premiership]]. This would allow work to be undertaken on their home ground of [[Castle Park rugby stadium|Castle Park]] in order to bring it up to at least the minimum seating capacity of 10,000 required by the [[Rugby Football Union|RFU]] and the Professional Game Board (PGB) for a premiership venue.{{cite web|last1=Hoden|first1=Liam|title=Doncaster Knights to ground share with Rovers if they win promotion to the Premiership|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/rugby-union/doncaster-knights/doncaster-knights-to-ground-share-with-rovers-if-they-win-promotion-to-the-premiership-1-7882655|website=The Star|publisher=Johnston Publishing Ltd.|accessdate=28 April 2016}} ==See also== * [[Belle Vue (football)|Belle Vue]], Doncaster Rovers' former home. * [[XP School]] ==References== {{Reflist|40em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Keepmoat Stadium}} * [http://www.keepmoatstadium.com Official website] {{Doncaster Rovers F.C.}} {{Navboxes|list1= {{Football League Two Venues}} {{FA WSL Venues}} {{RFL Championship Venues}} {{League 1 venues}} }} {{Portalbar|Yorkshire|English football|Rugby league|Women's association football}} [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Doncaster Rovers F.C.]] [[Category:Sports venues in Doncaster]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in England]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Football venues in South Yorkshire]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2006]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] [[Category:2006 establishments in England]] [[Category:American football venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Doncaster Rovers Belles L.F.C.]]

'''Park Hill Stakes''' is a [[Group races|Group 2]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in Great Britain open to [[Filly|fillies]] and [[mare]]s aged three years or older. It is run at [[Doncaster Racecourse|Doncaster]] over a distance of 1 mile, 6 furlongs and 115 yards (2,922 metres), and it is scheduled to take place each year in September. ==History== The event is named after Park Hill, an estate formerly owned by [[Anthony St Leger (British Army officer)|Anthony St. Leger]], the founder of Doncaster's most famous race, the [[St. Leger Stakes]]. The Park Hill Stakes was established in 1839, and it was originally restricted to three-year-old fillies. The victory of [[Blink Bonny]] in 1857 provoked a riot among spectators who believed she had been dishonestly prevented from winning the previous day's St. Leger.{{cite web | title = The Blink Bonny Disturbances | url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59868069 | publisher = [[National Library of Australia#Trove|Trove]] (Bell's Life in Sydney, 23 January 1858) | accessdate = 8 January 2012}} The present system of race grading was introduced in 1971, and the Park Hill Stakes was initially given Group 2 status. It was opened to fillies and mares aged four or older and relegated to Group 3 level in 1991. It was promoted back to Group 2 in 2004. The Park Hill Stakes is currently held on the second day of Doncaster's four-day St. Leger Festival. It is sometimes referred to as the Fillies' St. Leger. ==Records== '''Most successful horse:''' * ''no horse has won this race more than once'' '''Leading [[jockey]] (6 wins):''' * Sim Templeman – ''Calypso (1840), Sally (1842), Peggy (1843), Tiff (1850), Honeysuckle (1854), Clotilde (1855)'' * John Osborne, Jr. – ''Qui Vive (1859), Lady Trespass (1860), Agility (1870), Experiment (1880), Belinda (1884), Minthe (1889)'' '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (7 wins):''' * [[John Scott (horseman)|John Scott]] – ''Mickleton Maid (1839), Sally (1842), Peggy (1843), Canezou (1848), Honeysuckle (1854), Hepatica (1858), Toison d'Or (1869)'' * [[Noel Murless]] – ''Bara Bibi (1954), Collyria (1959), Bracey Bridge (1965), Pink Gem (1967, dead-heat), Parmelia (1970), Attica Meli (1972), Mil's Bomb (1974)'' ==Winners since 1975== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! {{Infobox basketball club | color1 = | color2 = | color3 = | name = Philadelphia Sphas | current = | logo = | imagesize = | conference = American League of Philadelphia (1917–1922)
Manufacturer's League (1923)
Philadelphia League (1923–1925)
Eastern League (1925–1926)
American Basketball League
(1926–1927, as Warriors)
Independent (1928–1929)
Eastern Basketball League (1929–1933)
American Basketball League (1933–1949, as Sphas) | division = | founded = 1917 (as Philadelphia YMHA)
1918 (as Sphas) | folded = December 31, 1959Stark, xiv. | history = Philadelphia YMHA (1917), Philadelphia Sphas (1918–1921, 1922–1926, 1927–1933, 1937–1959), Philadelphia Passon, Gottlieb, Black (1921–1923 in American League of Philadelphia and Manufacturers League),
Philadelphia Warriors (1926–1928 in the American Basketball League), Philadelphia Hebrews (1933–1937), Atlantic City Tides (1949){{cite book|last1=Stark|first1=Douglas|title=The SPHAS: The Life and Times of Basketball's Greatest Jewish Team|date=2011|publisher=Temple University Press|pages=267-287}} | arena = Broadwood Hotel (after 1933) | location = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] | colors = Red, white, blue | gm = [[Eddie Gottlieb]] | coach = Eddie Gottlieb (1917–1927)
[[Harry Litwack]] | league_champs = '''12''' (1 in Philadelphia League,
1 in Philadelphia Basket Ball League, 3 in EBL, 7 in ABL) }} The '''Philadelphia Sphas''', also stylized '''SPHAs''' or '''SPHAS''', were an American basketball franchise that existed in professional, semi-professional, and exhibition forms. They played their home games in the ballroom of Philadelphia's Broadwood Hotel. The team's name is an [[acronym]], derived from '''S'''outh '''P'''hiladelphia '''H'''ebrew '''A'''ssociation (the group that initially funded the team), and the team's players, at least in its earlier years, were primarily Jewish. Future [[Philadelphia Warriors]] owner [[Eddie Gottlieb]] founded the team as an amateur group shortly after he and some close friends graduated from high school, and the team evolved into a professional unit that played in many leagues around the Philadelphia area and the East Coast, most notably the Eastern Basketball League and the [[American Basketball League (1925–55)|American Basketball League]], between which the Sphas won 10 championships. The Sphas won a total of 12 championships, their first two coming from the early Philadelphia League and Philadelphia Basket Ball League. With the 1946 advent of the [[Basketball Association of America]], the immediate predecessor of the NBA, the ABL became a minor-league, and the Sphas would remain there as a semi-professional team until 1949. Gottlieb sold the team in 1950 to [[Red Klotz]], a former Spha. 1949 would be the last year the Sphas were affiliated with a league, but thanks to Gottlieb's friendship with [[Abe Saperstein]], president and owner of the [[Harlem Globetrotters]], the Sphas lived on as one of the exhibition teams that the Globetrotters would play, although they would retain only the franchise name, not the Jewish makeup of the team.Stark, xiv. Despite popular wisdom, the Sphas did not directly evolve into the [[Washington Generals]]. Instead, Saperstein had asked Klotz to create a separate exhibition team because the Sphas had beaten the Globetrotters on more than one occasion.{{Cite news|url=http://joeposnanski.com/a-basketball-carol/|title=A Basketball Carol|date=2011-01-05|work=Joe Posnanski|access-date=2018-01-11|language=en-US}}{{Cite book|title=The SPHAS: The Life and Times of Basketball's Greatest Jewish Team|last=Stark|first=Douglas|publisher=Temple University Press|year=2011|isbn=|location=|pages=219}} After creating the Generals, Klotz sold the Sphas to one of his players, Pete Monska, who coached the team "for a year or two until it disbanded [in October 1959.]" The Sphas played their last game as the original team on October 17, 1959, losing to the Globetrotters in a double-header exhibition game. The Sphas were then reconstituted as the Baltimore Rockets, another Globetrotters exhibition team.Stark, xiv. ==History== [[File:SPHAS BASKETBALL TEAM SIGN ON BROAD STREET.JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.3|[[Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission]] marker.]] ===Origins as YMHA=== The Sphas' existence began in 1917 as an amateur team by neighborhood friends [[Eddie Gottlieb]], Harry Passon, and Hughie Black, who wanted to keep their high school championship team together.Stark, 13. The team's [[1917-18 Philadelphia Sphas season|first season]] took place in the American League of Philadelphia, a minor league that comprised six area teams. They were sponsored by the Young Men's Hebrew Association of South Philadelphia, and were called Philadelphia YMHA for that season. The team turned in a 4–11 record, tied for last in the league that year.Stark, 13. After that season, the YMHA withdrew its support for the team, citing dissatisfaction with the game's violent nature. ===Change to Sphas and "Wandering Jews" period=== After losing their sponsorship from the YMHA, Gottlieb, Passon, and Black approached the South Philadelphia Hebrew Association about sponsoring the team. The association agreed to sponsor the men, and provided funding for uniforms to the team. The new uniforms featured the acronym SPHA in Hebrew (ספהא) across the front. Again, their sponsorial relationship was short-lived, as the SPHA withdrew their sponsorship shortly after for an unspecified reason.Stark, 14. The men had better financial solvency this time around, as they opened a sporting goods store, calling it P.G.B. Sporting Goods. With the store, they created new uniforms, but kept the Sphas moniker as a way of paying tribute to their upbringing. Douglas Stark, author of ''The SPHAS: The Life and Times of Basketball's Greatest Jewish Team'', noted that "[f]or a number of years, the team was known as the Wandering Jews, because the team did not have its own home court."Stark, 15. The team continued to play in the American League of Philadelphia after losing their partnership with the SPHA, and played in two different leagues during the 1922–23 season: The Manufacturer's League, containing teams from area companies, and the Philadelphia League, which consisted of teams from the greater Philadelphia area, a number of them religious. In their single season in the Manufacturer's League, the team (known as Philadelphia Passon, Gottlieb, Black since they competed through Passon and Black's sporting goods store) turned in an overall 8–6 record, finishing 3rd in the first half of that season and 6th (out of 8) in the second half.Stark, Appendix B, 271. Their first season in the Philadelphia League was a disappointing one, turning in an 8–11 record and finishing 2nd in the first half of the season, but last in the second half at 1–8.Stark, Appendix B, 272. The Sphas' next season in the Philadelphia League would prove more fruitful (due in part to the increased number of games), as the Sphas turned in a 25–15 record, overcoming a first half slump of 14–13 (5th out of 8) to finish first in the second half of the season with an 11–3 record. They went on that year to defeat the Tri-Council Caseys 2–0 for their first championship.Stark, Appendix B, 273 ===Early championships, success against barnstorming teams, first ABL stint and name change=== For the 1924–25 season, the Philadelphia League reconstituted itself as the Philadelphia Basket Ball League, dropping the number of teams in the league to six. The Sphas continued a strong spate of play, finishing 1st in the first half of the season, and third in the second half. They would go on to be repeat champions that season, winning 2–1 again over Tri-Council. Due to the success of the Sphas against teams in the Philadelphia area, and frustration with playing in the "poorly managed" Eastern League in 1924–25, owner Eddie Gottlieb set up games against professional teams from the newly-formed [[American Basketball League (1925–55)|American Basketball League]].Stark, 19. The Sphas played a six-game stretch against the [[Brooklyn Arcadians]], [[Fort Wayne Caseys]], [[Cleveland Rosenblums]], [[Washington Palace Five]], and a team from New York's Metropolitan League, the Paterson Legionaires. The Sphas won five out of six games in this series, and Gottlieb subsequently scheduled games against two top [[Barnstorm (sports)|barnstorming]] teams of the day, the [[Original Celtics]] and [[New York Renaissance]]. The Sphas defeated the Original Celtics 2–1 and swept the Rens, 2–0. The team's victories over these top barnstorming teams gave them increased notability in the burgeoning professional basketball community.Radel. Abe.“South Philadelphia Hebrew Association,” in The Reach Official Basket Ball Guide, 1926–27, ed. William Phillips (Philadelphia: A. J. Reach, 1926), 222. Riding the wave of victories his team achieved against the ABL and barnstorming teams, Gottlieb entered the Sphas in the ABL, rechristening them the Philadelphia Warriors. During their two years in the ABL as the Warriors, the team performed moderately well, finishing third (14–7) and then fourth (10–11) in the 1926–27 season.Stark, 20. For the 1927–28 season, the ABL split into two divisions (Eastern and Western). The Warriors played in the Eastern Division and finished third with a 30–21 record. This allowed them entry into the playoffs, where they lost to the New York CelticsThis team was in reality the [[Original Celtics]], who replaced the Brooklyn Arcadians. They took the name Brooklyn Celtics, then changed to New York Celtics for the 1927 season. 2–0.Stark, Appendix B, 275. ==Season-by-season records== {{Main|List of Philadelphia Sphas seasons}} ==Players== {{Main|Philadelphia Sphas all-time roster}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Philadelphia Sphas| ]] [[Category:1917 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:1955 disestablishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Jewish-American history]] [[Category:Sports entertainment]] [[Category:Sports in Philadelphia]]

13,000http://www.aps.dz/sport/40188-r%C3%A9ouverture-officielle-du-stade-benabdelmalek-ramdane-de-constantine ([[Football(soccer)|football]],(athletics))
| dimensions = }} '''Benabdelmalek Ramdane Stadium''' ({{lang-ar| ملعب رمضان بن عبد المالك}}) is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Constantine, Algeria|Constantine]], [[Algeria]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. The stadium holds 13,000 people. It serves as a home ground for [[MO Constantine]] and [[CS Constantine]]. {{coord|36|20|57|N|6|37|33|E|type:landmark|display=title}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Football venues in Algeria]] [[Category:Sports venues in Algeria]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Constantine, Algeria]] {{Algeria-sports-venue-stub}}

{{National rugby union | unionname = Rugby Union of Serbia | nativename = Ragbi Savez Srbije | logo = Ragbi savez Srbije logo.jpg | logosize = 180px | founded = 1954 | IRB = 1988 | region = [[Rugby Europe|RE]] | regionyear = 1964 | president = Stevan Ilijašević | coach = Michel Milovic | womenscoach = Milan Orlović | url = {{url|http://www.rugbyserbia.com/}} }} The '''Rugby Union of Serbia''' ({{lang-sr|Ragbi Savez Srbije|script=Latn}}) is the governing body for [[rugby union]] in [[Serbia]]. It was founded in 1954 and joined [[Rugby Europe]] (formerly FIRA-AER) in 1964.<ref name=re-page/> It has been a member of [[World Rugby]] (formerly the IRB) since 1988.<ref name= wr-book-2014/><ref name = irb-serbia-2009/>
==Leadership==
'''Rugby Union of Serbia'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rugbyserbia.com/ragbi-savez-srbije/|title=Ragbi Savez Srbije – Ragbi savez Srbije|website=rugbyserbia.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-25}}</ref>
* President of the Alliance: Danilo Bulatovic * President of the Assembly: Goran Vuković * General Secretary: Mr Stevan Ilijasevic * Technical Director: Marko Jovanović * Competition and Registration Commissioner: Ana Vidojevic
'''Managing Board''' * President: Danilo Bulatović, Belgrade * Vice President: Igor Stojadinović, Pančevo * General Secretary: Stevan Ilijašević, Belgrade * Member: Goran Porobić, Novi Sad * Member: Mario Kržić, Ruma
'''Supervisory Board''' * President: Goran Višnjić * Member: Miro Arsenijević * Member: Miomir Kalabić
'''Competition Commission''' * President: Goran Višnjić * Member: Branislav Vila * Member: Viktor Džanković
'''Other League Officials''' * Disciplinary Judge: Dipl. Right. Sonja Inđić * President of the Judicial Organization: Dejan Štiglić * Chairman of the Delegation: Goran Vuković * President of the Organization of Health Workers in Rugby: Dr Srđan Nikolić
'''National Team of Serbia''' * Director: Marko Milosavljevic * Manager: Slavisa Milenkovic * Selector: Nikola Orlandic * Coach: Aleksandar Poprecica * Coach: Marko Milosavljevic
==Teams== *[[Serbia national rugby union team|Serbia]] - the national men's rugby union team. *[[Serbia national rugby union team (sevens)|7s]] - the national men's rugby union seven-a-side team. *[[Serbia women's national rugby union team|Serbia]] - the national women's rugby union team. *[[Serbia women's national rugby union team (sevens)|7s]] - the national women's rugby union seven-a-side team.

{{Multiple issues |{{Notability|Films|date=October 2011}} {{no footnotes|date=June 2012}} }} {{Infobox film | name = The Harlem Globetrotters | image = HarlemGlobetrottersFilmPoster.jpg | image_size = 220 | caption = Dorothy Dandridge and Bill Walker in 1951 theatrical poster. | director = [[Phil Brown (actor)|Phil Brown]]
Will Jason | starring = [[Thomas Gomez]]
Bill Walker
[[Dorothy Dandridge]] | music = Arthur Morton | cinematography = [[Philip Tannura]] | editing = [[James Sweeney (film editor)|James Sweeney]] | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1951|10|24}} | runtime = 78 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = }} '''''The Harlem Globetrotters''''' is a 1951 [[List of sports films|Sport]]/[[Drama film|Drama]] film about the famous [[African American]] [[basketball]] team [[The Harlem Globetrotters]] released by [[Columbia Pictures]]. The film stars [[Thomas Gomez]], Bill Walker, [[Dorothy Dandridge]], [[Angela Clarke (American actress)|Angela Clarke]], and Peter M. Thompson. ==Trivia== The film has not been released on U.S. home video. It premiered on television on Turner Classic Movies (TCM) on May 29, 2012. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=23em}} *[[Thomas Gomez]] as Coach Abe Saperstein *Bill Walker as Prof. Turner *[[Dorothy Dandridge]] as Ann Carpenter *Angela Clarke as Sylvia Saperstein *Peter M. Thompson as Martin *Billy Brown as Billy Townsend (Globetrotter) *[[Roscoe Cumberland]] as Roscoe (Globetrotter) *[[William 'Pop' Gates]] as 'Pop' Gates (Globetrotter) *[[Marques Haynes]] as Marques (Globetrotter) *[[Louis 'Babe' Pressley]] as 'Babe' Pressley (Globetrotter) *[[Ermer Robinson]] as Elmer Robinson (Globetrotter) *[[Ted Strong]] as Ted Strong (Globetrotter) *[[Reece 'Goose' Tatum]] as 'Goose' Tatum (Globetrotter) *[[Frank Washington]] as Frank Washington (Globetrotter) *[[Clarence Wilson (actor)|Clarence Wilson]] as Clarence Wilson (Globetrotter) {{div col end}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0043621|The Harlem Globetrotters}} *[http://www.tcm.com/schedule/search.html?type=schedule&text=harlem A link to the feature on TCM's website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Harlem Globetrotters}} [[Category:1951 films]] [[Category:American basketball films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Harlem Globetrotters]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:1950s drama films]] [[Category:1950s sports films]] [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:African-American biographical dramas]] {{sport-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox sport | name = Cross country running | image = Sahara Race 2011.jpg | alt = | imagesize = 220px | caption = Ultramarathoners compete at the Sahara Race 2011 ([[4 Deserts]]). | union = [[International Association of Athletics Federations|IAAF]] | nickname = | first = | firstlabel = | region = | registered = | clubs = | contact = | team = | mgender = | type = | equipment = | venue = | olympic = | world = 1987- | paralympic = | obsolete = }}
An '''ultramarathon''', also called '''ultra distance''' or '''ultra running''', is any footrace longer than the traditional [[marathon]] length of {{convert|42.195|km|mi}}.
==Overview== There are two types of ultramarathon events: those that cover a specified distance, and events that take place during time (with the winner covering the most distance in that time). The most common distances are {{convert|50|km|mi|3}}, {{convert|100|km|mi|3}}, {{convert|50|mi|km|4}}, and {{convert|100|mi|km|4}}, although many races have other distances. The 100 kilometers is recognized as an official world record event by the [[International Association of Athletics Federations]] (IAAF), the world governing body of track and field.<ref name="IAAF 100 km Records">{{cite web|url=http://www.iaaf.org/records/toplists/road-running/100-kilometres/outdoor/men/senior |title=– 100 Kilometres Records |publisher=Iaaf.org |date= |accessdate=2013-10-05}}</ref>
Other distances/times include double marathons, [[24-hour run|24-hour races]], and [[multiday races]] of {{convert|1000|mi}} or even longer. The format of these events and the courses vary, ranging from single loops (some as short as a {{convert|400|m|sing=on}} track),<ref>If the loop is less than {{convert|1|km}}, run direction changes every 2–4 (sometimes 6) hours [Citation Needed~~~~Mark Halsey]</ref> to point-to-point road or trail races, to cross-country [[rogaining|rogaines]]. Many ultramarathons, especially [[trail running|trail challenges]], have severe course obstacles, such as inclement weather, elevation change, or rugged terrain. Many of these races are run on [[dirt road]]s or [[trail|mountain paths]], though some are run on paved roads as well. Usually, there are [[aid station]]s every {{convert|20|to|35|km}} apart, where runners can replenish food and drink supplies or take a short break. Timed events range from 6, 12, and 24 hours to 3, 6, and 10 days (known as ''multi-day'' or "stage race" events). Timed events are generally run on a track or a short road course, often one mile (1.6 km) or less.<ref name="IAAF Ultra Running">{{cite web|url=http://www.iaaf.org/disciplines/ultra-running/ultra-running |title=Ultra Running |website=Iaaf.org |date= |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref>
Considered to be a tougher event are self-supported ultramarathon stage races where each competitor has to carry all their supplies including food to survive the length of the race, typically a week. A good example of this is the Grand to Grand Ultra, America's first ever self-supported ultramarathon stage race.
The [[International Association of Ultrarunners]] (IAU) organises the World Championships for various ultramarathon distances, including {{convert|50|km}}, {{convert|100|km}}, 24 hours, and ultra [[trail running]], which are also recognized by the IAAF. Many countries around the world have their own ultrarunning organizations, often the national athletics federation of that country, or are sanctioned by such national athletics organizations. World records for distances, times, and ages are tracked by the IAU.
[[Racewalking]] events are usually 50 km, although [[100 kilometres race walk|100 km]] and [[Centurion (racewalking)|100 mile]] (160 km) "Centurion" races are also organized. Furthermore, the non-competitive [[International Marching League]] event Nijmegen Four Days March has a regulation distance of 4 × 50 km over three days for men aged 19–49.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.4daagse.nl/en/register/distance-rewards.html |title=Vierdaagse - Distance & Rewards |website=4daagse.nl |date= |accessdate=2016-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107120104/http://www.4daagse.nl/en/register/distance-rewards.html |archivedate=7 November 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

==World or national-record holding or world-championship-winning ultramarathon runners== For reliable and updated information, see the IAU (International Association of Ultrarunners) annual report of current world records on its newest "World's Best Performances" page in statistics.
* [[Yiannis Kouros]], multi-day race legend, holder of numerous world records and world bests from 24 hours to 1,000 miles, course record holder of the [[Spartathlon]] since its inception in 1983<ref name="IAAF 100 km Records"/><ref name="iau-ultramarathon.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.iau-ultramarathon.org/images/file/IAU_WBP_WABP_201405.pdf |format=PDF |title=IAU 50km Women & Men |date=2014-05-14 |website=Iau-ultramarathon.org |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> * [[Takahiro Sunada]], current men's '''100 km Road''' world record holder (6:13:33, [[Lake Saroma Ultramarathon|Saroma]] JP, 1998)<ref name="IAAF 100 km Records"/><ref name="iau-ultramarathon.org"/> * [[Tomoe Abe]], current women's '''100 km Road''' world record holder (6:33:11, [[Lake Saroma Ultramarathon|Saroma]] JP, 2000)<ref name="IAAF 100 km Records"/><ref name="iau-ultramarathon.org"/> * [[Ryōichi Sekiya]], four time IAU [[24-hour run]] World Championship winner, Asia record holder of 24-hour run |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> * [[Sumie Inagaki]], current women's '''24h Indoor''' world record holder ({{convert|240.631|km|miles}} Espoo FIN, Jan 2011),<ref name="iau-ultramarathon.org"/> current of [[IAU]] [[24-hour run]] World Championship<ref name="ReferenceA"/> * [[Suprabha Beckjord]] female and [[Wolfgang Schwerk]] male record holder [[Self-Transcendence 3100 Mile Race|3100 mile Race]] <ref name="scr">{{cite web|url=http://3100.srichinmoyraces.org/about |title= srichinmoyraces.org / About the 3100 Mile Race |date= |accessdate=2013-01-16}}</ref> * [[Edit Berces]], '''24 hour treadmill''' world record holder; holds several Hungarian records * [[Ted Corbitt]], "father of American ultrarunning"; 1952 US Olympic team member; former American world record holder at various record holder (6:25:07) * [[Serge Girard]], trans-USA (4,597 km – 1997), trans-South America (5,235 km – 2001), trans-Africa (8,295 km – 2003/2004) and trans-Eurasia (19,097 km – 2005/2006) record holder * [[Wally Hayward]], Multiple winner of Comrades Marathon, London to Brighton, many other ultramarathons; set early world records * [[Bernd Heinrich]], formerly held the '''US 100 mile track''' |publisher=Jewishsports.net |date= |accessdate=24 February 2013}}</ref> * [[Frith van der Merwe]], set Comrades Marathon records for both directions * [[Stu Mittleman]], US record holder for six-day race (578 miles) * [[Arthur F. H. Newton]], 5 times Comrades Marathon winner * [[Elena Nurgalieva]] and her sister [[Olesya Nurgalieva]] have won a total of 10 Comrades Marathon titles between them; Elena holds the uphill course record (6:09:24) * [[Ann Trason]], fourteen time Western States Endurance Run winner and former female course record holder; 2-time winner of the [[Comrades Marathon]]; formerly or currently holds numerous American and World Records; '''American 100k''' record holder (7:00:48) * [[Cliff Young (athlete)|Cliff Young]], former winner Westfield Sydney to Melbourne; holds numerous world age records{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * [[Arun Bhardwaj]], first Indian to compete in and win the [[George Archer 6 day]] race in South Africa, completed a 4,000+ km run from Kargil, India to Kanyakumari, India, in 61 days.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * [[Camille Herron]], first ultra athlete to win 2 World titles in the same year (2015- 50K and 100K); 2017 Comrades Marathon Champion; holds the World Best for 50 Miles (5:38:41), '''100 Mile Road and Trail World Record''' (12:42:40), and 12 Hour World Record.
==Ultramarathons by regions== Ultra Marathons are run around the world with more than 70,000 people completing them every year.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
===Africa=== Several ultra distance events are held in Africa.
* South Africa hosts a number of notable ultra marathon events. ** On paved surface: the world's oldest and largest ultramarathon, the {{convert|87|km}} [[Comrades Marathon]]. Approximately 12,000 runners complete the Comrades each year, out of approximately 17000 who start, with 23,961 competing in 2000.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140604101237/http://raceday.comrades.com/home-about/history-of-comrades ]</ref> ** The {{convert|56|km|sing=on}} [[Two Oceans Marathon]] in [[Cape Town]] in the southern autumn attracts approximately 11,000 runners. ** The Washie 100 road race is the oldest one hundred miler road race in Africa. ** Off road: The Salomon Sky Run is a gruelling {{convert|100|km}} self-supported, unmarked trail race held in a particularly scenic part of the country. ** Trail: The [[Peninsula Ultra Fun Run]] (PUFfeR) {{convert|80|km}} supported, unmarked trail run crossing the Table Mountain range in Cape Town South Africa. * The [[Marathon des Sables]] is a 6-day stage race which covers {{convert|250|km}} through the [[Sahara desert]] in [[Morocco]]. * The Sahara Race in Egypt, part of the [[4 Deserts]] series, is held annually with about 150 competitors from 40 countries competing. Due to political instability, the ultramarathon of {{convert|250|km}} has temporarily relocated to the [[Namib Desert]]. * The [[Grand Raid de la Réunion]] is held annually on [[Réunion]] in October, crossing the island over {{convert|163|km}} with an altitude gain of {{convert|9643|m}}. This race attracts 2,350 competitors, with 1,000 runners from overseas.
===Asia=== Ultrarunning has become popular in Asia recently, and countries such as [[Japan]], [[Taiwan]], and [[South Korea]] have hosted IAU World Championships.
*Japan had its first 100 km event in 1987 as [[Lake Saroma Ultramarathon]] and hosted [[International Association of Ultrarunners|IAU]] 100 km World Championship in 1994 ([[Lake Saroma Ultramarathon|Lake Saroma]]), 1998 ([[River Shimanto Ultramarathon|River Shimanto]]) and 2005 ([[Lake Saroma Ultramarathon|Lake Saroma]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iau-ultramarathon.org/images/file/IAU%20100km%20World%20Cup%20Results%201987%20to%202008.pdf |format=PDF |title=IAU World Cup 100 Kilometres |website=Iau-ultramarathon.org |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> Japan hosts more than 50 ultramarathon events throughout the year,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marathons.ahotu.com/calendar/ultramarathon/japan |title=2016 - 2017 Japan Ultramarathon Calendar |website=Marathons.ahotu.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> among which are [http://www.tjar.jp/2012/about/index.html [[Trans Japan Alps Race]] (TJAR)] ({{convert|415|km|mile}} with more than {{convert|26,000|m|mile}} cumulative altitude gain crossing Japan Alps, crossing Japan's mainland from Japan Sea to Pacific Ocean in 7 days),<ref>NHK team, 激走! 日本アルプス大縦断 密着、トランスジャパンアルプスレース富山~静岡415km, 26 Apr 2013, {{ISBN|978-4087815276}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.dreamnews.jp/press/0000072853/ |title=日本一過酷な山岳レース「トランスジャパンアルプスレース（TJAR）」に密着したノンフィクション書籍『激走！ 日本アルプス大縦断』（NHKスペシャル取材班・著）が、集英社より4月26日（金）に発売！ | 株式会社 集英社 | プレスリリース配信代行サービス『ドリームニュース』 |website=Dreamnews.jp |date= |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> [[Hasetsune cup]] ({{convert|71.5|km|mile}} in steep foggy mountains)<ref>RUNTRAIL editors, RUN+TRAIL vol.2 トレイルランレースをはじめよう ハセツネ/UTMF完走法 (SAN-EI MOOK),22 Aug 2012, {{ISBN|978-4779615627}}</ref> and [http://www.ultratrailmtfuji.com/ Ultra-Trail Mt. Fuji (UTMF)] ({{convert|161|km|mile}} loop around World Heritage [[Mt. Fuji]] with cumulative altitude gain of about {{convert|9,000|m|mile}}).<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.irunfar.com/2013/04/2013-ultra-trail-mount-fuji-preview.html |title=2013 Ultra-Trail Mount Fuji Preview |website=Irunfar.com |date=2013-04-24 |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://info.japantimes.co.jp/works/ultra-trail-mount-fuji.html#.UxBgnfKYbIU |title=Ultra-Trail Mt. Fuji (UTMF) | The Japan Times Online |website=Info.japantimes.co.jp |date= |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> * South Korea's first ultramarathon was held in 2000. * The Gobi March in northwest China was China's first ultramarathon, first staged in 2003. The Gobi March is part of the 4 Deserts Race Series.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.4deserts.com/gobimarch |publisher=4 Deserts Official Website |title=The Gobi March}}</ref> * India's first ultra marathon, the Bangalore Ultra was held in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bangaloreultra.com |publisher=The Bangalore Ultra |title=The Bangalore Ultra |accessdate=28 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/12/14/stories/2007121456852200.htm |publisher=''[[The Hindu]]'' |title=Big response for the Bangalore Marathon |date=14 December 2007 |accessdate=28 April 2013}}</ref> Since 2010, Indian Himalayas have hosted ''La Ultra – The High'', a 333 km course crossing [[Khardung La]], touted to be the world's highest motorable mountain pass.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://forbesindia.com/article/recliner/why-la-ultra-the-high-is-the-cruelest-marathon/34723/1 |publisher=Forbes India |title=Why La Ultra The High is the Cruelest Marathon |date=18 February 2013}}</ref> * Soochow International 24H Ultra-Marathon is held since 1999 in [[Taipei]], and is an official IAU-registered event. * A night race called the [[Sundown Marathon]] has been held in Singapore annually since 2008, over a double marathon distance (84 km) up to 2010 and 100 km since then.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sundownmarathon.com/index.php?page=home-ultramarathon |title=Sundown Marathon |publisher=HiVelocity |accessdate=28 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420070944/http://www.sundownmarathon.com/index.php?page=home-ultramarathon |archive-date=20 April 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * [[Nepal]] hosts several ultramarathon races,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trailrunningnepal.org/events/ |title=Nepal events |publisher=Trail Running Nepal}}</ref> including the Annapurna 100, the Kanchenjunga Ultra Marathon Trail Running Race <ref>{{cite web|url=http://annapurna100.com/|title=Annapurna 100 |publisher=annapurna100.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-05}}</ref> and the Everest Ultra.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.everestultra.com/ |title=Everest Ultra |publisher=Everest Ultra |date=2013-03-30 |accessdate=2013-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131013134317/http://everestultra.com/ |archivedate=13 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>. Running a total of 1,504 km in a bit more than 24 days, [[Ryan Sandes]] and Ryno Griesel set a new fastest known time during March 2018 for the [[Great Himalaya Trail]]. * Northern [[Mongolia]] hosts an annual 100 km summer race, [[Mongolia Sunrise to Sunset]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ms2s.org/ |title=Mongolia Sunrise to Sunset |publisher=Ms2s.org |date= |accessdate=2013-10-05}}</ref> * Malaysia's first ultra trail marathon was founded in November 2011 and is known as the TMBT (The Most Beautiful Thing) in Sabah at Mount Kinabalu, South East Asia's highest mountain. The event has a 55% drop out rate and is a 3-point qualifying race for Ultra Du Mont Blanc and a 2-point qualifying race for the 55 kilometer category of the event. This was followed by the Beaufort Ultra Marathon in Sabah organized in 2012 and a 60 kilometer endurance run under 35-39 degree Celsius morning and afternoon heat with a 60% finish rate amongst runners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sabahadventurechallenge.com |title=Sabah Adventure Races |publisher=Sabahadventurechallenge.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-05}}</ref> First 100 miles ultra marathon road race, Putrajaya 100 Miles, was held on 22–23 November 2014. The first 200 km ultra will be held on 6–8 March 2015 in Titi, Selangor (TITI100). Other ultra races such as Back2Endurance, G5N, and Gunung Nuang Ultra were organized by the Malaysia Ultra Running * [[Indonesia]]'s first ultramarathon race, Mount Rinjani Ultra (52K), was held on August 2013 and Indonesia's first 100K & 160K ultramarathon race, Bromo Tengger Semeru 100 Ultra, was held on November 2013. Tambora Challenge (320KM) held from 2015 * In the [[Cebu]], [[Philippines]], Ultramarathons has gained quite a number of followers. An [[All-Women Ultra Marathon]] race covering a distance of 50 kilometers is held annually on the weekend of [[International Women's Day]] since 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/AWUM/1457443814483028 |title=AWUM |publisher=[[Facebook]] |date= |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> * Clark Freeport Zone in the Philippines is the venue for two of the Philippines premier ultramarathon events. The Clark Miyamit Ultra, known as CM50 a 60K and 50Mile Trail Ultramarathon that takes runners to traverse from Clark to the Aeta Villages, lahar bed, mountain ranges near Mt. Pinatubo and the iconic Miyamit Falls. Cardimax - Clark Ultramarathon is a road ultramarathon of 50K and 100K distance which brings and gathers ultramarathoners from aspiring ones to the most competitive elites. * In [[Israel]], two major ultramarathon races are commenced annually - ''Mount to Valley'' relay race; over 215 km, from the hills of the [[Upper Galilee]] to the [[Jezreel Valley]], and the ''Valley Circle'' race in the Jezreel valley; contains several distances, including 160 km and 200 km.
===Oceania, Australia, and New Zealand=== Australia and New Zealand are hosts to some 100 organized ultramarathons each year. Additionally a handful of runners have run the entire length of New Zealand, a distance of around {{convert|2200|km}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.endurancesport.co.nz/feature.cfm?id=104 |title=Endurance Sport |publisher=Endurance Sport |date= |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> The most recent runners being [http://www.lisatamati.co.nz Lisa Tamati] and [[Andrew Hedgman]] who both completed the challenge separately in 2009 and 2010.
'''Australia'''
In Australia, the [[Westfield Ultra Marathon]] was an annual race between Sydney and [[Melbourne]] contested between 1983 and 1991. Greek runner [[Yiannis Kouros]] won the event five times during that period. Australia is also the home of one of the oldest [[6 Day Race|six-day race]]s in the world, the [[Cliff Young Australian 6-day race]], held in [[Colac, Victoria]]. The race is held on a 400-meter circuit at the Memorial Square in the centre of Colac, and has seen many close races since its inception in 1984. The 20th Cliff Young Australian six-day race was held between 20 and 26 November 2005. During that event, Kouros beat his existing world record six-day track mark and set a new mark of {{convert|1036.851|km}}. The [[Coast to Kosciuszko]] inaugurated in 2004, is a {{convert|246|km|mi|adj=on}} marathon from the coast to the top of [[Mount Kosciuszko]], Australia's highest mountain.
Australia has seen a steep growth in Ultrarunning events and participants in recent years. Many new races have come into inception, covering a range of Ultramarathon distances from 50 km right through to multi-day events. The cornerstone of Australian Ultra events being such races as; Ultra-Trail Australia 100, Bogong To Hotham, Alpine Challenge, and the Cradle Mountain Run.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150321112809/http://www.rapidascent.com.au/salomontrailrunning/WhatIsTrailRunning ]</ref> The Australian Ultra Runners Association (AURA) has a comprehensive list and links of events and their respective results.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071012145302/http://aura.asn.au/events.html ]</ref>
In 2018 two Australians became the 7th (Thomas Cripps) and 8th (Roger Box) people to be admitted to the [http://www.official7continentsmarathonclub.com/member_list/finisher_list Official 7 Continents Ultramarathon Club].
'''New Zealand''' New Zealand's first ultramarathon called The [[Kepler Challenge]] was held on a {{convert|60|km}} trail through [[Fiordland National Park]], which has been running since 1988 and is one of the country's most popular races. New Zealand's [http://www.northburn100.co.nz Northburn 100 ultra mountain run] is the first 100-mile (160 km) race through the Northburn Station. The world-famous Te Houtaewa Challenge has a 62 km race on ninety mile beach, Northland. The field of international and local runners have to contend with rising tides and soft beach sand and the March race dates often means the race is run in the cyclone season. In 2014 the ultramarathon was postponed because of Cyclone Lucy. In 2016 the race will be in its jubilee and the 25th anniversary will see many of its past runners compete for the honour of the ultimate challenge winner. The [[Tarawera Ultramarathon]] is currently one of the most competitive ultras in New Zealand and part of the Ultra-Trail World Tour.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taraweraultra.co.nz/ultra-trail-world-tour/|title=The Tarawera Ultramarathon 102km is part of the global Ultra-Trail ® World Tour .|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
In November 2012, [[Kim Allan]] planned to run and/or walk {{convert|500|km}} nonstop, without sleep, on the [[Sri Chinmoy]] Peace Mile track at the [[Auckland Domain]]. Her aim was to beat ultrarunner [[Pam Reed]]'s record of {{convert|300|mi}}.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Two-feet-500km-and-no-sleep-for-charity/tabid/423/articleID/275649/Default.aspx |work=3 News NZ | first=Dan| last=Satherley | title= Two feet, 500km and no sleep for charity| date=7 November 2012}}</ref> According to her [[Facebook]] page, she only managed {{convert|385.8|km}}. She eventually passed the 500 kilometre mark at 86 hours, 11 minutes, and 9 seconds, breaking the {{convert|486|km}} women's record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11176746 |title=Ultra-distance runner breaks record - National - NZ Herald News |website=Nzherald.co.nz |date=2013-12-22 |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref>
In April 2013, a [[Feilding]] man, Perry Newburn, set a new New Zealand record by running {{convert|483|km}} without sleep at Feilding's Manfield Park.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Feilding-father-breaks-NZ-running-record/tabid/423/articleID/293113/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Feilding father breaks NZ running record| date=5 April 2013}}</ref>
Ultramarathon running in New Zealand has a national body: the New Zealand Ultrarunners Association.
'''Oceania''' [[Papua New Guinea]] has the [[Kokoda Track#Kokoda Challenge Race|Kokoda Challenge Race]], an annual 96 km endurance race held in late August that runs the length of the historic [[Kokoda Track]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Kokoda Challenge|url=http://www.kokodatrail.com.au/kokodachallenge.html|publisher=Kokoda Trekking|accessdate=24 June 2011}}</ref>
Papua New Guinea also has the Great Kokoda Race, a multi-stage 96 km (3 day) race held in early July where competitors run or walk the length of the [[Kokoda Track]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Great Kokoda Race|url=http://www.greatkokodarace.com|publisher=Twisted Explorer|accessdate=13 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913082812/http://www.greatkokodarace.com/|archivedate=13 September 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Europe=== In Europe, ultrarunning can trace its origins with early documentation of ultrarunners from [[Iceland]]ic [[saga]]s{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}, or ancient Greece from where the idea of the [[Marathon]], and the [[Spartathlon]] comes. The history of ultrarunners and walkers in the UK from the [[Victorian Era]] has also been documented. The IAU hosts annual European Championships for the [[IAU 50 km European Championships|50 km]], [[IAU 100 km European Championships|100 km]] and [[IAU 24 hours European Championships|24 hours]]. The [[European Ultramarathon Cup]] is an annual cup event covering some of the biggest Ultramarathon races in Europe.<ref>[http://www.laufreport.de/nachrichten/press/index3.htm 25 years of ECU]</ref> Also worth mentioning is the ultramarathon [[CajaMar Tenerife Bluetrail]], the highest race in [[Spain]] and second in [[Europe]],<ref>[http://www.abc.es/deportes/abci-tenerife-bluetrail-carrera-mas-alta-espana-201610060829_noticia.html Tenerife Bluetrail, la carrera más alta de España]</ref> with the participation of several countries and great international repercussions.
There are over 300 ultramarathons held in Europe each year,{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}. This includes the [[Harz Run]] in the [[Harz Mountains]], the Irish [[Connemarathon]], the British [[Bob Graham Round]], [[Spine Race]] and Welsh [[Dragon's Back]] which covers 315km with 15,500m of height gain <ref>[http://www.berghausdragonsbackrace.com/details/#displayROUTEInformation]</ref>.
===Antarctica=== Due to logistics and environmental concerns there are only a handful of ultramarathons held in Antarctica, and travel costs can mean entrance fees as high as $14,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.icemarathon.com/live/146.html |title=Antarctic Ice Marathon 2013 |publisher=Icemarathon.com |date=2013-03-07 |accessdate=2013-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131001121438/http://www.icemarathon.com/live/146.html |archivedate=1 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Ultramarathons in Antarctica include: [[The Last Desert]], part of the 4 Deserts Race Series, a multi-stage footrace, and the [[Antarctic Ice Marathon]] – a marathon and 100-kilometer race.
===North America=== There are several hundred ultramarathons held annually in North America. One of the best known is the [[Western States Endurance Run]], the world's oldest 100-mile trail run. The race began unofficially in 1974, when local horseman Gordy Ainsleigh's horse for the 100-mile [[Tevis Cup]] horse race came up lame. He decided to travel the course on foot, finishing in 23 hours and 42 minutes.<ref>{{cite web |title=How it All Began |url=https://www.wser.org/how-it-all-began/ |website=wser.org |accessdate=24 October 2018}}</ref>
One of the first documented ultramarathons in North America was held in 1926, and at the time was part of the [[Central American Games]]. Tomas Zafiro and Leoncio San Miguel, both [[Tarahumara]] Indians, ran 100 km from [[Pachuca]] to Mexico City in 9 hours and 37 minutes. At the time, the Mexican government petitioned to include a 100 km race in the [[1928 Summer Olympics]] in [[Amsterdam]]{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}; however, nothing came of these efforts.
In 1928, sports agent [[C. C. Pyle]] organized the first of two editions of the 3,455-mile-long [[Bunion Derby]] (the first went along [[U.S. Route 66]] from Los Angeles to Chicago before heading toward New York; the 1929 Derby reversed the route). Neither the race nor the accompanying [[vaudeville]] show was a financial success.
Since 1997, runners have been competing in the [[Self-Transcendence 3100 Mile Race]], which is billed as the longest official footrace in the world. They run 100 laps a day for up to 50 days around a single block in Queens, NY, for a total distance of {{convert|3100|mi|km}}.<ref name=scr/> The current recordholder is [[Ashprihanal Pekka Aalto]], at 40 days 09:06:21 for a daily average of {{convert|76.776|mi|km}} in 2015.
The latest [[Trans-American Footrace]] (2015) winner was [[Robert HP Young]] (Marathon Man UK) Winning in a time of 482 hours 10 minutes 00 seconds <ref name="Race Across USA Results">{{cite web|url=http://raceacrossusa.org/results/ |format=PDF |title=Results : RAUSA Results |website=Raceacrossusa.org |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref>
In April 2006, the [[American Ultrarunning Hall of Fame]] was established by the [[American Ultrarunning Association]] (AUA). Candidates for the Hall of Fame are chosen from the 'modern era' of American ultras, beginning with the [[New York Road Runners]] Club 30 Mile race held in 1958. The Inaugural inductees were [[Ted Corbitt]], a former US Olympian, winner of the aforementioned race in 3:04:13, and co-founder of the [[Road Runners Club of America]], and [[Sandra Kiddy]], who began her ultra career at age 42 with a world record at 50 kilometers, 3:36:56, and who went on to set a number of US and world ultra records.
===South America=== There are a small number of ultramarathons in South America, but participation in the sport is increasing. The '' Brazil 135 Ultramarathon'' is a single-stage race of 135 miles ( 217 km) with a 60-hour cutoff, held in Brazil. This is a Badwater "sister race".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110705183816/http://www.brazil135.com.br/pages/index.php ]</ref> Several ultramarathons are held in [[Chile]] and with both local and international participation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livingatlaschile.com/?s=Ultramarathoner |title=Ultramarathoner | Atlas Vivo de Chile |website=Livingatlaschile.com |date=2015-06-16 |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> Ultramarathons held in Chile include: *Atacama Xtreme 50K, 80K and the first 100 Miles in Chile. One loop for each distance starting and finishing in San Pedro de Atacama at an avg. of 2,400 above sea level.<ref>"A running battle". ''Toronto Star'', September 26, 2016. pages E1 and E5.</ref> * The Endurance Challenge, a 10K, 21K, 50K and 80K trail running race held in the Andes mountain range near [[Santiago]]. It is part of the global Endurance Challenge circuit. The race seeks to promote the sport, outdoor activity and the use of mountain trails, taking care to have the lowest impact possible on the environment. * The [[Lican Ray]]-[[Villarrica, Chile|Villarrica]] Ultramarathon, a 70 km marathon that starts in [[Lican Ray]], climbs [[Villarrica Volcano]] and ends in downtown Villarrica. * The Atacama Crossing, established in 2004, a 250 km (155 mile) ultramarathon which takes place in the [[Atacama desert]], around [[San Pedro de Atacama]], [[Chile]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140202101204/http://www.extrememarathonguide.com/the-atacama-crossing-race/]</ref> and crosses through the driest place on earth. There are six stages in seven days, with almost four marathons run in the first four days, then a 74 km stretch, then a rest day and a final stage of 11 km. It is part of the [[4 Deserts]] Series. The race covers rugged terrain, with a harsh climate and an altitude that averages 2500 m (8000 ft). The race uses the town of [[San Pedro de Atacama]] as its host town, and in 2012 the race began at its highest point of over 3,000m in the Arcoiris Valley. [[File:AtacamValley.jpg|thumb|View from the Atacama Crossing 2011.]] * The Patagonian International Marathon, organized by NIGSA, takes place in [[Torres del Paine National Park]], southern [[Chilean Patagonia]]. The event features four race distances: an ultramarathon (63 km), marathon (42 km), half marathon (21 km) and a 10K. Each distance has a different starting point, but everyone finishes in the same place. The event has the secondary goal of promoting the conservation of Chilean Patagonia and contributing to the sustainable development of the region through the planting of trees in the [[Torres del Paine National Park]] through the "Corre y Reforesta" (Run and Reforest) campaign<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eldefinido.cl/actualidad/pais/942/Corre_y_reforesta_la_Patagonia_chilena_con_la_maraton_de_Torres_del_Paine/ |title=Corre y reforesta la Patagonia chilena con la maratón de Torres del Paine |website=Eldefinido.cl |date= |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> run by the organization "Reforestemos Patagonia" (Let's Reforest Patagonia)<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20131005084513/http://www.reforestemospatagonia.cl/en ]</ref> * The Rapa Nui GrandTrail, an 80k ultramarathon that takes place on [[Easter Island]], [[Valparaíso Region]], [[Chile]]. This exotic trail, far out in the [[Pacific Ocean]], takes in the famous [[Moai]] statues of the island.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.active.com/easter-island/running/trail-run/rapa-nui-grand-trail-80k-2013 |title=RAPA NUI GRAND TRAIL 80K 2013 |website=ACTIVE.com |date=2013-10-27 |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref>
==International Trail Running Association (ITRA)== Many ultramarathon organizers are members of the [[International Trail Running Association]] (ITRA), an organization which promotes values, diversity, health and safety during races, as well as working to further the development of trail running and helps to coordinate between the national and international bodies with an interest in the sport. ITRA also evaluates of the difficulty of specific ultramarathon routes according to a number of criteria, such as the distance, the cumulative elevation gain, and the number of loops and stages. ITRA maintains a calendar of ultramarathon events.

{{Use American English|date=May 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name= Estádio Vivaldo Lima | image= FUTEBOL - panoramio (1).jpg | nickname= Vivaldão | location = Av. Constantino Nery, 4611-5201, [[Flores, Manaus|Flores]], [[Manaus]], [[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|AM]], [[Brazil]] | renovated= 1995 | opened= April 5, 1970 | closed= 2010 | demolished= 2011 | capacity= 31,000 | dimensions= 108 x 70 m | surface= Grass | owner= [[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Governo do Estado do Amazonas]] | architect= [[Severiano Mário Porto]] }} '''Estádio Vivaldo Lima''', usually known by its nickname '''Vivaldão''', was a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Manaus]], [[Brazil]]. It was formerly used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches. The stadium held 36,000, with 31,000 seats. It was built between 1958 and 1970.
The Vivaldão was owned by the government of [[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Amazonas state]]. The stadium was named after Vivaldo Lima, who was the founder of [[Nacional Fast Clube]] and it was the home ground of [[América Futebol Clube (AM)]], [[Nacional Futebol Clube]] and [[Atlético Rio Negro Clube]].
The stadium was demolished in 2011 and replaced by the [[Arena da Amazônia]].
==History== In 1970, construction of the Vivaldão was completed. The inaugural match was played on April 5 of that year, when [[Brazil national football team|Brazil national football team B]] beat Amazonas State All-Stars team B 4-1, followed by the match of the teams A, also 4-1. The first goal of the stadium was scored by Brazil B's [[Dadá Maravilha]].
The stadium's record attendance was 56,950, set on March 9, 1980 when Fast Clube and [[New York Cosmos (1970–85)|New York Cosmos]] of the [[United States]] drew 0-0.
== Demolition == On May 31, 2009, Manaus was chosen as one of the host cities of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]. The city's project involved the demolition of the Vivaldão, and a new stadium built in its place, the [[Arena da Amazônia]], with a capacity of 41,000 people. About R$580,000,000 was invested in the construction of the new stadium, which will include sport and recreation areas and a shopping mall.
The stadium was closed on March 19, 2010, and demolition began on July 12.
==References== *''Enciclopédia do Futebol Brasileiro'', Volume 2 - Lance, Rio de Janeiro: Aretê Editorial S/A, 2001.
